filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s Notebook, based on fresh digital photography from the British Library and presented in Preview mode—with enlargements and basic bibliographical information but without transcriptions. Usually works in Preview mode lack illustration descriptions as well, but in this case the minutely detailed descriptions for each illustration in the Notebook are available—and fully searchable along with the text and, of course, the rest of the Archive.
What we now think of as Blake’s Notebook was probably begun by his younger brother Robert for sketching and then preserved by William after Robert's early death in 1787. Used sporadically, first for sketches—among many others, the early illuminated book Songs of Experience, the emblem book Gates of Paradise, and later Jerusalem—and then for more and more poems and prose, from A Vision of the Last Judgment to a projected Public Address on the history and state of engraving to miscellaneous memoranda on his craft—"To Wood cut on Pewter"—and his life—"Tuesday Janry. 20. 1807 between Two & Seven in the Evening‐Despair" or, more upbeat, "23 May 1810 found the Word Golden."
He filled the book from front to back and then turned it around and filled it from the other direction. He crammed its nooks and crannies. Then in 1818 he returned to the Notebook to draft the remarkable Everlasting Gospel in the few scattered spaces that remained—not quite enough, because he tacked on an extra fold of previously used paper for a bit more writing room.
We are fortunate that, shortly after her husband’s death, Blake's wife Catherine seems to have passed the Notebook on to artist William Palmer (brother of better known artist and closer friend of William Blake, Samuel Palmer). Why William Palmer we don't know, but that route bypassed Frederick Tatham, who inherited what was left of William Blake in Catherine’s hands at her death. In an outbreak of religious fervor that led Tatham to reject Blake’s infernal heresies, he eventually burned a considerable stash, contents mostly unknown. Safe from the flames, the Notebook went eventually from Palmer to Dante Gabriel Rossetti at a propitious time before Blake was slated for dramatic revival through the efforts of Alexander Gilchrist, his wife Anne, and their helpful associates and informants, including the Rossetti brothers, Dante and William. They were careful to minimize Blake’s objectional side as they shaped surviving materials. Dante Rossetti bound the Notebook with his own heavily edited transcription of “All that is of any worth in the book.”
The underlying pattern is familiar. Blake’s work became a well from which his sponsors withdrew the items “of any worth” for their project of rehabilitating Blake in a form suitable to advanced tastes of the third quarter of the nineteenth century—featuring an archetypal multimedia artistic genius with spiritual dimensions while downplaying elements that might feed the notion that their “Pictor Ignotus” was simply insane. It would take a new generation, led by E. J. Ellis and William Butler Yeats, in their lavish and extensive three-volume Works of William Blake, Poetic, Symbolic, and Critical, Edited with [296] Lithographs of the Illustrated “Prophetic Books,” and a Memoir and Interpretation (1893), to reach deeper into the well to retrieve stranger (and in most quarters less acceptable) writing and images as they constructed their unorthodox Blake with strong mystical inclinations.
Artists’ notebooks are often dissected and analyzed, of course, as part of the deep background for the genesis and evolution of texts and images. Editors of twentieth century printed editions almost always sorted items from the Notebook into meaningful literary categories—“Satiric Verses and Epigrams,” “Songs and Ballads,” “Miscellaneous Prose”—leaving little trace of the book as a whole—and of course omitting images altogether. But Blake’s Notebook, like its artistic kin, can and should also be considered as an integral work, in this case the work of a lifetime, unlike any other that he left us.
In The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Blake imagines a Printing House in Hell whose apocalyptic output—created by dragons, vipers, eagle-like men, and lions of flaming fire—"took the forms of books & were arranged in libraries” (plate 15, Erdman page 40), there to await suitably apocalyptic readers to open the pages and liberate the volatile content. Artists’ notebooks, more than most books, declare their dynamic energies outright. Open the pages and you know instantly that you must participate. Blake’s Notebook, taken as a whole, as its own special kind of book, makes potent demands on its readers—and promises to connect us to an artistic life lived more than 200 years ago in ways that the preprocessed letterpress versions, indispensable as they are, simply cannot.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: Robert Blake delineator. William Blake's brother Robert, who died in 1787, apparently owned the notebook and made use of it before it passed to William. The drawings on Objects 5, 7, 8, 11, 13, and 15 are very probably his work.
objdescid.compdate: c. 1787-1818Robert Blake used the notebook before his death in 1787. William Blake may not have begun using it until c. 1790.

objinfo.numberleaves: 61Objects 9-10 (the recto and verso of a single leaf) is a modern piece of paper to which a drawing, formerly pasted to Object 8, has been mounted.
objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, and monochrome wash
objinfo.watermark: Fragments of an unidentified countermark appear on 58 leaves.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-120 in pencil on Objects 1-8, 11-122These pencil numbers were added to the top outer corner of each page by William A. White sometime between 1887 and 1927 when he owned the notebook. The modern leaf of paper inserted as Objects 9-10, to which a leaf of Blake's drawings is attached, is numbered "5" upper right on its recto (Object 9).
objinfo.binding: half moroccoThe original leather binding was removed between 1847 and 1882 and replaced with half leather over marbled boards, but with the original spine retained. This second binding was replaced by the present binding c. 1934.
objinfo.stabholes: none recordedThe leaves have been mounted on stubs since at least 1882.

provenance.name: British Library
provenance.note: Acquired in 1787 by William Blake from his brother Robert by inheritance; William Blake's wife, Catherine, by inheritance in 1827; Samuel Palmer's brother, William, by gift or purchase; Dante Gabriel Rossetti in April 1847 by purchase from William Palmer (possibly for £10); sold from Rossetti's collection, T. G. Wharton, Martin & Co. auction, London, 7 July 1882, lot 483 (£110); the London dealer Ellis & White, offered in their catalogue 52 of c. 1883, item 67, with "Rossetti's copy" of Alexander Gilchrist, *Life of William Blake*, edition not specified but probably 1863 (£250); sold by F. S. Ellis, Sotheby's, 18 Nov. 1885, lot 608, with Rossetti's copy of Gilchrist (£85 to the dealers G. I. Ellis & J. P. Scrutton, successors to Ellis & White and F. S. Ellis); the New York dealers Dodd, Mead & Co.; sold to William A. White of Brooklyn, Jan. 1887 ($825); White's daughter, Mrs. Frances White Emerson, by inheritance in 1927; given by Emerson to the British Museum (now British Library) in 1957.

objnote.p: For a similar design, also probably representing Daphne, see Object 38.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the center of the page a nude, long-haired female, probably Daphne, facing right and twisted away with her head bent back, raises her arms, each of which terminates in multiple branches that arc and hang down, some as far as the level of her waist. The branches are probably meant to represent a laurel tree, as in the classical myth of Daphne. Her feet extend into roots on either side of her. She stands on a slight mound. An upside down unidentified face is visible behind the text in the lower right. When viewed upright, the face is turned slightly to the left. For another drawing of Daphne, see object 38.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center of the page a nude, long-haired female, probably Daphne, facing right and twisted away with her head bent back, raises her arms, each of which terminates in multiple branches that arc and hang down, some as far as the level of her waist. The branches are probably meant to represent a laurel tree, as in the classical myth. Her feet extend into roots on either side of her. She stands on a slight mound.
The figure stands on a small mound.
An upside down unidentified face is visible behind the text. When viewed upright, the face is turned slightly to the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Centered near the top of the page is a nude male figure seen from behind, running or struggling forward, possibly with the coil of a serpent around his left calf. His upper body is bent down and to the right. A few lines below his crotch may be his penis. His arms are indistinguishable; a few lines right of his right knee are uncertain. Below the striding figure is the head of a man, facing left in quarter profile. He may be wearing a hat. Dark markings make some of his features, such as his mouth, indeterminate.

component.illusobjdesc: Centered near the top of the page is a nude male figure seen from behind, running or struggling forward, perhaps with the coil of a serpent around his left calf. His upper body is bent down and to the right. A few lines below his crotch may be his penis. His arms are indistinguishable; a few lines right of his right knee are uncertain.
There may be the coil of a serpent around the left calf of the striding figure.
Below the striding figure is the head of a man, facing left in quarter profile. He may be wearing a hat. Dark markings make some of his features, such as his mouth, indeterminate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The main design consists of a domestic bedroom scene. A curly-haired male, possibly William Blake, sits on the edge of a bed. He wears a shirt, stockings, and shoes. He is facing left and bending forward. His right leg is drawn up and crossed so that his right ankle rests on his left knee. His left arm is extended so that his hand rests on his raised left ankle; he may be in the act of pulling on shoes or stockings. To the right of the male figure is another figure, probably female, lying on her right side in the bed. This may be William Blake's wife, Catherine. Her bent left arm is visible, resting on the bed covers. She may be sleeping. To the left of the bed is a table, atop which appears to be another, indeterminate object. The table is centered below a window. In the upper left corner of the page is a portion of a head seen in left profile, from the forehead to the end of the nose. To the right of the partial profile is another face seen in left profile, but here the eyes, mouth, and chin are visible.

component.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired male, possibly William Blake, sits on the edge of a bed. He wears a shirt, stockings, and shoes. He is facing left and bending forward. His right leg is drawn up and crossed so that his right ankle rests on his left knee. His left arm is extended so that his hand rests on his raised left ankle; he may be in the act of pulling on shoes or stockings.

To the right of the male figure is another figure, probably female, lying on her right side in the bed. This may be William Blake's wife, Catherine. Her bent left arm is visible, resting on the bed covers. She may be sleeping.
The couple is on a bed with pillow, blanket, and possibly sheets. The left bedpost and footboard are visible in the foreground.
To the left of the bed is a table, atop which appears to be an indeterminate object.
The table is centered below a window.
In the upper left corner of the page is a portion of a head seen in left profile, from the forehead to the end of the nose.
To the right of the partial profile is another face, probably male, seen in left profile, but here the eyes, mouth, and chin are visible.

objnote.p: The pencil drawing on this page is probably the work of Robert Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. A group of five(?) figures, perhaps Druids, stands in a row. All but one of the figures have been erased so that they are nearly indeterminate. The unerased figure is male, as appears to be the figure to his right. The unerased figure has his head turned to the right. His arms are at his side, but they are bent at the elbow and raised with the palms at shoulder level, facing the viewer. His fingers may be slightly spread. He wears a robe or gown with what may be a belt below his chest. This drawing is probably by Robert Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: A group of five(?) figures, perhaps Druid, stands in a row. All but one of the figures have been erased so that they are nearly indeterminate. The unerased figure is male, as appears to be the figure to his right. The unerased figure wears a gown or robe with what may be a belt below his chest.

The unerased figure is male and stands facing forward, with his head turned to the right. His arms are at his side, but they are bent at the elbow and raised with the palms at shoulder level, facing the viewer. His fingers may be slightly spread. He wears a robe with what may be a belt below his chest.

objnote.p: The drawings are preliminary sketches for Blake's headpiece to "The Elephant," the first ballad in William Hayley, *Designs to a Series of Ballads*, 1802. See also Object 94.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper left portion of the page a tiger crouches facing right, with mouth open and tail raised. The tiger's teeth and tongue are suggested. Shading on the tiger indicates fur, but not stripes. It is looking up at the figure of a man in a window set above an arched doorway to the right of the tiger. There may be a cloth, such as a loincloth, over his genital area. The man's lower body faces forward, but his upper body is twisted so that it faces right. His legs are spread and his right leg is bent at the knee; only his left upper thigh is visible within the window frame. He may be straddling the windowsill in an effort to climb inside. He leans away from the tiger and his right arm is extended (only the shoulder is visible). He may be looking back toward the tiger over his right shoulder. Below the crouching tiger is a detailed drawing of the head of a tiger, facing right with mouth open and teeth and possibly the tongue visible.

component.illusobjdesc: On the upper left portion of the page a tiger crouches facing right, with mouth open and tail raised. The tiger's teeth and tongue are suggested. shading on the tiger suggests fur, but not stripes. It is looking up at the figure of a man in a window above and to the right of the tiger.

A male figure can be seen in a window above an arched doorway. There may be cloth, such as a loincloth, over his genital area. His lower body faces forward, but his upper body is twisted so that it faces right. His legs are spread and his right leg is bent at the knee; only his left upper thigh is visible within the window frame. He may be straddling the windowsill in an effort to climb inside. He leans away from the tiger and his right arm is extended (only the shoulder is visible). He may be looking back toward the tiger over his right shoulder.
The man appears in a window above an arched doorway in a building. There may be a pillar or pilaster left of the door.
Below the crouching tiger is a detailed drawing of the head of a tiger, facing right with mouth open and teeth and possibly tongue visible.

objnote.p: The pencil drawing on this page is probably the work of Robert Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. Three figures (perhaps Druids) stand in a row, facing forward. The central figure appears to be male, and wears a hat and ruffled collar. The sex of the outer two figures is unclear, although both are probably male. All three figures wear robes or gowns. The central figure faces forward, apparently being led by the two figures next to him. Both arms are at his side, bent at the elbow, and raised so that the forearms are horizontal and extended forward. His wrists are clutched in the angle formed by the bent arms of the two figures on either side of him, and his hands hang limp before him. The robed figure on the left is facing forward and stepping toward the viewer with his right foot. Its right arm is at its side and its left arm is bent at the elbow such that its forearm extends across its chest. In the angle formed by its bent left arm, the figure holds the right wrist of the central figure, perhaps leading him forward. The robed figure on the right is facing forward with his head turned to the left, looking at the central figure. Both arms are at his side, but both are bent at the elbow such that his left forearm extends across his waist. His right forearm may extend across his chest. Like the figure on the left, he holds the left wrist of the central figure in the angle formed by his bent right arm, perhaps leading him forward. This drawing is probably by Robert Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: The central figure in the group of three figures (possibly Druids) appears to be male, and wears a hat, robe, and ruffled collar. He faces forward, apparently being led by the two figures next to him. Both arms are at his side, bent at the elbow, and raised so that the forearms are horizontal and extended forward. His wrists are clutched in the angle formed by the bent arms of the two figures on either side of him, and his hands hang limp before him.

The robed figure on the left in the group of three figures (possibly Druids) is of uncertain sex but is probably male. He is facing forward, stepping toward the viewer with his right foot. His right arm is at his side and his left arm is bent at the elbow such that his forearm extends across his chest. In the angle formed by his bent left arm, the figure holds the right wrist of the central figure, perhaps leading him forward.

The robed figure on the right is perhaps a male Druid and is facing forward, with his head turned to the left, looking at the central figure. Both arms are at his side, but both are bent at the elbow such that his left forearm extends across his waist. His right forearm may extend across his chest. Like the figure on the left, she holds the left wrist of the central figure in the angle formed by her bent right arm, perhaps leading him forward.

objnote.p: The pencil drawing on this page is very probably the work of Robert Blake. The drawing now mounted on the leaf bearing Objects 9-10 was formerly pasted to the lower portion of this object.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page contains a very light, possibly partly erased, pencil sketch, drawn sideways, many of the features of which are indeterminate. There are at least four figures on the right. On the right, once the page is rotated so the figures are upright, three robed figures (perhaps Druids) stand facing left. The two rightmost figures have their left arms at their sides. All four figures figure appear to be raised on a pedestal or plinth. The figure third from the left has his left arm extended; he is placing what may be a crown or wreath of laurels on the head of another figure, who kneels below to the left, facing the standing figure. The kneeling figure's arms are bent and his hands may be held together at the level of his chest, in a posture of supplication or prayer. To the left and slightly below the figures on the platform, a group of at least three robed figures kneels, facing right. Their arms may be raised, with hands together, in a posture of supplication.

component.illusobjdesc: The page contains a very light, possibly partly erased, pencil sketch, drawn sideways, many of the features of which are indeterminate. There are at least four figures on the right. On the right, once the page is rotated so the figures are upright, three robed figures (perhaps Druids) stand facing left. The two rightmost figures have their left arms at their sides. All four figures figure appear to be raised on a pedestal or plinth. The figure third from the left has his left arm extended; he is placing what may be a crown or wreath of laurels on the head of another figure, who kneels below to the left, facing the standing figure. The kneeling figure's arms are bent and his hands may be held together at the level of his chest, in a posture of supplication or prayer.

To the left and slightly below the figures on the platform, a group of at least three robed(?) figures kneels, facing left. Their arms may be raised, with hands together, in a posture of supplication or prayer.

objnote.p: This modern leaf of paper has been used as a mount for a drawing by Blake formerly pasted to the lower portion of Object 8. This Object 9 shows the verso of that drawing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fragment of what may be a robed figure is visible, but much is indeterminate, given that most of the original leaf has been cut away. The figure's left(?) arm is pictured. A portion of the fist is visible, and it may be holding an indeterminate object.

component.illusobjdesc: A fragment of what may be a clothed figure is visible, but much is indeterminate, given that most of the original leaf has been cut away. The figure's left(?) arm is pictured. A portion of the fist is visible, and it may be holding an indeterminate object.

objnote.p: This modern leaf of paper has been used as a mount for a drawing by Blake formerly pasted to the lower portion of Object 8. This Object 10 shows the recto of that drawing, a preliminary sketch for figures in *Europe a Prophecy*, Bentley Plate 5.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A group of three wrestlers, all nude males, appears to hover in mid-air. The central nude, muscular male has his legs spread, with his right leg extended and his left leg bent at the knee so that his left heel is pressed against his left thigh. He has short hair and appears to be smiling. He looks down and to the left. With his left arm he grasps a bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's right arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. The figure on the right has his legs spread and bent at the knees. His body is horizontal with torso facing upward, but his head is twisted so that it is facing forward. He tries, with both hands, to release the central males arm from around his neck. His face expresses pain and terror, and his mouth is open. The wrestler on the left has his legs spread, with his right leg extended vertically and his left leg bent at the knee. His left arm is bent back over his shoulders and grasps the right leg of the central male. His body is horizontal and facing up, but his head is bent back as he is being strangled, such that his head is upside down and facing forward. His mouth is open and his face expresses pain and terror.

component.illusobjdesc: The central nude, muscular male in the group of three wrestlers hovering in mid-air has his legs spread, with his right leg extended and his left leg drawn up and bent so that his left heel is pressed against his left thigh. He looks down and to the left. He has short hair and may be smiling. With his left arm he grasps a bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's right arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand.

The figure on the right in the group of three nude male wrestlers hovering in mid-air has his legs spread and bent at the knees. His body is horizontal with torso facing upward, but his head is twisted so that it is facing forward. He tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. His face expresses pain and terror, and his mouth is open.

The wrestler on the left in the group of three nude males has his legs spread, with his right leg extended vertically and his left leg bent at the knee. His left arm is bent back over his shoulders and grasps the right leg of the central male. His body is horizontal and facing up, but as he is being strangled by the central figure, his head is bent back so that it is upside down and facing forward. His mouth is open and his face expresses pain and terror.

objnote.p: The monochrome wash drawing on this page is very probably the work of Robert Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. On the right, a robed female figure flees through a forest. Her long hair blows behind her and her right arm is pressed to her side and bent upward so that her hand is at the level of her breast. Her right foot is visible below the hem of her gown. To the left of the woman and emerging from the doorway of a Gothic building, a large male knight strides to the right, pursuing the fleeing female. He has a mustache and wears a helmet and full armor. His left arm is at his side and a shield is strapped to it. His right arm is bent and he holds a sword upright. The woman flees into a forest, which serves as the background for the design. Numerous trunks are visible, including one in the foreground, between the woman and the knight. Lines and dark wash at the top of the trunks indicate the forest canopy, while dark. This drawing is very probably by Robert Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female figure flees through a forest. Her long hair blows behind her and her right arm is pressed to her side and bent upward so that her hand is at the level of her breast. Her right foot is visible below the hem of her gown. There may be a belt visible on her back.

Perhaps emerging from the doorway of a Gothic building, a large male knight strides to the right, pursuing the fleeing female. He has a mustache and wears a helmet and full armor. His left arm is at his side and a shield is strapped to it. His right arm is bent and he holds a sword upright.

The knight appears to be emerging from the arched doorway of a Gothic structure. His body is framed by two pillars that support several arches extending outward from above the doorway, which is framed by two pillars or pilasters. This might be a castle or a church.

The woman flees into a forest, which serves as the background for the design. Numerous trunks are visible, including one in the foreground, between the woman and the knight. Lines and dark wash at the top of the drunks indicate the forest canopy.

objnote.p: The pencil drawing on this page is probably the work of Robert Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to view the design upright. On the right, a crowned king stands facing forward and to the left and looking to the left. His right arm is raised horizontally with his palm down, perhaps pointing toward a retreating figure to the left. His left arm is at his side. The train of his robe or cape is held by three figures, who are perhaps kneeling behind him. Walking away from the king, with its back to the viewer, is a robed figure of indeterminate gender. Its left arm is at its side and its right arm is raised at nearly 45 degrees. To the left of this figure are three or four gowned figures, indeterminately sketched. Both the king and the figure he is pointing at appear to be standing on clouds. In the lower left corner of the design is a supine figure, facing up. He may be a giant, given his size relative to the king and the two figures sitting at his head. His arms are at his side and he may be wearing a gown robe, but his lower body is indeterminate. He may be dead; if so, this may be a burial scene. Two small figures kneel or sit on either side of the giant's head. The figure on the left faces right and slightly away from the viewer. Its right arm is at its side and it may be wearing a robe or gown; its gender is indeterminate. The figure on the right faces forward and is behind the giant's head and left shoulder, and thus only its head and upper body are visible. No facial features are visible. These drawings are probably by Robert Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: On the upper right, a crowned king stands facing forward and looking to the left. His right arm is raised horizontally with his hand palm down, perhaps pointing toward a retreating figure to his left. His left arm is at his side. The train of his robe or cape is held by three supplicants or retainers, who are perhaps kneeling behind him.
The train of the king's robe or cape is held by a group of three figures, who perhaps kneel behind him. Only their heads and upper bodies are visible. The face left.

Walking away from the king, with its back to the viewer, is a robed or gowned figure of indeterminate gender. Its left arm is at its side and its right arm is raised at 45 degrees. The figure faces forward but strides to the left.
To the left of the figure with its back turned are three or four robed or gowned figures, indeterminately sketched. They may be standing.
Both the king and the figure he is pointing at appear to be standing on clouds.

In the lower left of the design is a supine figure, facing up. He may be a giant, given his size relative to the king and the two figures sitting at his head. His arms are at his side and he may be wearing a robe, but his lower body is indeterminate. He may be dead; if so, this may be a burial scene.

Two small figures kneel or sit on either side of the giant's head. The figure on the left faces right and slightly away from the viewer. Its right arm is at its side and it may be wearing a robe or gown; its gender is indeterminate.

Two small figures kneel or sit on either side of the giant's head. The figure on the right faces forward and is behind the giant's head and left shoulder, so only its head and upper body are visible. No facial features are visible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the upper half of the page, the head of a male, perhaps Henry the Eighth, is drawn, facing forward. He has curly hair and wears a hat and collar. Below and to the right of the head of Henry is another man's head, facing forward, perhaps with curly hair. His features are less pronounced than the figure above, and he is covered by lines of text.

component.illusobjdesc: On the upper half of the page, the head of a male, perhaps Henry the Eighth, is drawn, facing forward. He has curly hair and wears a hat and collar.

Below and to the right of the head of Henry the Eighth is another man's head, facing forward, perhaps with curly hair. His features are less pronounced than the figure above, and he is covered by lines of text.

objnote.p: The monochrome wash drawing on this page is very probably the work of Robert Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the lower right corner of the design, a couple reclines in an open poppy blossom. The nude male, perhaps Oberon, rests on his left elbow. He faces left, with his left leg extended and his right leg bent. His right arm is at his side and his right hand may be resting on his knee. To the right of and below the male figure, a female nude, perhaps Titania, reclines. She also faces left, has long hair, and her legs are together. Her right arm is at her side and her left arm is extended horizontally away from her body. Two leaves and the stem of another poppy are visible below the open blossom. The lower blossom arches to the lower left corner of the design, so that only a portion of it is visible. Growing up from the lower left corner of the page is a lily plant containing three large leaves that arch to the right and two blossoms which hang over the open poppy blossom and the reclining figures. Directly beneath the foremost lily blossom is a ring of perhaps five hovering fairies, all of them gowned and holding hands. This drawing is very probably by Robert Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male, perhaps Oberon, reclines in an open poppy blossom, resting on his left elbow. He faces left, with his left leg extended and his right leg bent. His right arm is at his side and his right hand may be resting on his knee. He may be wearing a crown.

To the right of and below the male figure, a female nude, perhaps Titania, reclines. She also faces left, has long hair, and her legs are together. Her right arm is at her side and her left arm is extended horizontally away from her body.

The two figures recline inside an open poppy blossom whose stem extends toward the bottom of the page. Two leaves and the stem of another poppy are visible below the open blossom. The lower blossom arches to the lower left corner of the page, so that only a portion of it is visible.

Growing up from the lower left corner of the page is a lily plant containing three large leaves that arch to the right and two blossoms which hang over the open poppy blossom and the reclining figures.
Directly beneath the foremost lily blossom is a ring of perhaps five hovering female(?) fairies, all of them gowned and holding hands.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of the page is an indeterminate sketch of what may be a fingertip or an erect penis.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the page is an indeterminate sketch of what may be a fingertip or an erect penis.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 16 in both versions. The inscription below this emblem design,"Thus the traveller hasteth in / the Evening", serves as a caption. The sketch lower left of a standing figure and a dog may be related to (but is not a direct preliminary for) the man and dog lower left in "On Anothers Sorrow" in *Songs of Innocence*, Bentley Plate 27.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a male traveler strides boldly to the right. He wears a coat, breeches, shoes, and a broad-brimmed hat. His right arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm raised horizontally and he holds a walking-stick in his right hand. A long shadow extends from his left foot. Dark pencil marks above and behind him might indicate clouds and/or sky, as well as leafy trees or large plants in the background. In the upper left corner of the page a male wearing a coat or shirt and hat stands with his back to the viewer, legs spread. He may also wear a skirt, or pants with wide legs, held at the waist with a belt. He is urinating beside a door, wall, or pillar, located to the right. Three versions of a soaring human figure—bearded, with flame-like hair and arms extended horizontally—with a dead(?) nude body in its mouth are located above (two versions, the larger figure above) and to the right (the third version, seen in closest detail) of the central emblem. Lines trailing from the figures suggest that their bodies are descending. The soaring figures, perhaps demons, goblins, or devils, may be eating the limp bodies. This might also be Saturn eating one of his offspring. In the lower left, a figure stands, looking down at the dog sitting to the right. To the right and slightly below the boy and dog is a curving trunk of a tree, without crown or branches. To the left of the emblem, a nude(?) infant, probably dead, lies face up with its head to the right, near a plow located to the left. To the left and slightly above the central emblem are the back view of a left leg drawn to just below the knee and the side view of a left(?) foot, facing left.

component.illusobjdesc: A male traveler strides boldly to the right. He wears a coat, breeches, shoes, and a broad-brimmed hat; he holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm raised horizontally. A long shadow extends from his left foot.
Dark pencil marks above and behind the traveler might indicate clouds and/or sky.
Pencil marks behind the traveler might indicate leafy trees or large plants in the background.

In the upper left corner of the page a male wearing a coat or shirt and hat stands with his back to the viewer, legs spread. He is urinating beside a door, wall, or pillar located to the right. He appears to be wearing a skirt, or pants with wide legs, held at the waist with a belt.
A door, wall, or pillar is located to the right of the urinating traveler.

Three versions of a soaring human figure—bearded, with flame-like hair and arms extended horizontally—with a dead(?) nude body in its mouth are located above (two versions, the larger figure above) and to the right (the third version, seen in closest detail) of the central emblem. Lines trailing from the figures suggest that their bodies are descending. The soaring figures, perhaps demons, goblins, or devils, may be eating the limp bodies.
To the right and slightly below the human figure and dog is a curving trunk of a tree, without crown or branches. A few lines at its base suggest roots.
A figure stands, looking down at the dog sitting to the right.
A dog, sitting to the right of the human figure, looks up at him, its head bent back.
To the left of the emblem, a nude(?) infant, probably dead, lies face up with its head to the right, near a plow located to the left.
To the left of the supine child is a plow, pointed left.
To the left and slightly above the central emblem are the back view of a left leg drawn to just below the knee and the side view of a left(?) foot, facing left.

objnote.p: The standing figure seen from behind, lower left, may be related to (but is not a direct preliminary for) the figure in the frontispiece to *Jerusalem*, Bentley Plate 1.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A giant flying devil, goblin, or demon descends from the top of the page. It is nude and muscular, with arms spread wide—first drawn horizontally and then redrawn at the angle of descent—and palms down, fingers spread. It faces forward and left and in its open mouth it bites, eats, or at least holds a limp human figure, probably dead. To the left of this figure is an indeterminate sketch of what may be a hand with two or three fingers discernible. This may be a detail for the hand of the flying figure at the top of the page. Below and slightly to the right of the giant flying demon at the top of the page is another, slightly larger, giant flying demon in the same posture. It is also nude and muscular, with arms spread wide. This figure also faces forward and left and in its open mouth it bites, eats, or at least holds a limp human figure, probably dead. To the left of the lower flying giant is a detail of buttocks, seen from behind. Below the flying demons, in front of what might be a doorway, a gowned female(?) figure stands with arms raised at 45 degrees. It is uncertain whether she faces forward—toward an approaching male to the left—or away. She is flanked by three children. The shortest is to the left of her and appears to be holding her leg. The two other children are to the right of her; the tallest appears to have a hat dangling from a ribbon. The woman's hand may be on the shoulder of the tallest child. To the right of the woman and children are two separate indeterminate details, perhaps of body parts. To the left and slightly below the woman and children is another detail of buttocks, seen from behind. In the lower left corner of the page is a nude, muscular male, seen from behind. He is striding with his right foot forward, perhaps approaching the woman and children. His left arm is bent and raised at 45 degrees, with the fingers of his left hand spread. His hair may be curly.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper left quadrant of the page is an indeterminate sketch of what may be a hand with two or three fingers discernible. This may be a detail for the hand of the flying figure at the top of the page.

A giant flying devil, goblin, or demon descends from the top of the page. It is nude and muscular, with arms spread wide—first drawn horizontally and then redrawn at the angle of descent—and palms down, fingers spread. It faces forward and left and in its open mouth it bites, eats, or at least holds a limp human figure, probably dead.
Clasped in the mouth of the flying goblin is a limp human figure, probably dead, with arms and legs dangling.

Below and slightly to the right of the giant flying demon at the top of the page is another, slightly larger, giant flying devil, demon, or goblin in the same posture. It is also nude and muscular, with arms spread wide. This figure also faces forward and left and in its open mouth it bites or holds a limp human figure, probably dead.
Clasped in the mouth of the flying goblin is a limp human figure, probably dead, with arms and legs dangling.
To the left of the lower flying giant is a detail of buttocks, seen from behind.

In front of what might be a doorway, a gowned female figure stands with arms raised at 45 degrees. It is uncertain whether she faces forward—toward the approaching male—or away. She is flanked by three children, one to the left and two to the right. Her hand may be on the shoulder of the tallest child.

Three children of indeterminate gender stand beside the woman. The shortest is to the left of her and appears to be holding the leg of the woman. The two other children are to the right of her; the tallest appears to have a hat dangling from a ribbon. The woman's hand may be on the tallest child's shoulder.

component.characteristic: The woman and children stand before what may be a large rectangular doorway.

component.illusobjdesc: To the right of the woman and children are two separate indeterminate details, perhaps of body parts.
To the left and slightly below the woman and children is a detail of buttocks, seen from behind.

In the lower left corner of the page is a nude, muscular male, seen from behind. He is striding with his right foot forward, perhaps approaching the woman and children. His left arm is bent and raised at 45 degrees, with the fingers of his left hand spread.

objnote.p: The lines inscribed below the central emblem, "Are glad when they can find / the grave", serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a male traveler is seen from behind climbing the steps into the open doorway, probably of a tomb or grave. He wears breeches, a shirt, a belt, and a broad-brimmed hat. He holds a staff or walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is raised and he may be pushing or fending off the hooded and robed figure of a skeletal personification of Death, who stands in the doorway and who may be holding a scythe. In the upper left corner of the page are two versions of the lower half of a giant face. These may be demons, devils, or goblins. In the upper version the nose is visible. He has long hair, beard, and mustache. His mouth is open and his teeth are visible, biting, clasping, or possibly eating a limp nude corpse, whose legs and arms dangle in front of the giant's chin. The lower version is slightly larger. Here the corpse can be seen to have long hair, and its dangling legs are crossed at the ankles.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a male traveler is seen from behind climbing the steps into the open doorway, probably of a grave or tomb. He wears breeches, a shirt, a belt, and a broad-brimmed hat. He holds a staff or walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is raised, fingers spread, and he may be pushing or fending off the figure of Death, who stands in the doorway. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees.

Standing in the doorway of the tomb and facing the entering traveler is the hooded and robed figure of a skeletal personification of Death, who may be holding a scythe in his left hand. The traveler may be pushing or fending off the figure of Death, whose head is a skull.
The traveler climbs the steps into the open doorway of a tomb, where the figure of Death stands.

In the upper left corner of the page are drawn two versions of the lower half of a giant face. These may be devils, goblins, or demons. In the upper version the nose is pictured. He has long hair, beard, and mustache. His mouth is open and his teeth are visible, biting, clasping or possibly eating the limp nude corpse, whose legs and arms dangle in front of the demon's chin.

A limp nude corpse of indeterminate gender is being bitten, clasped, or possibly eaten in the mouth of a demon or devil highest on the page. The corpse is facing up, its head is bent back, and its arms and legs are dangling in front of the demon's chin.

In the upper left corner of the page are drawn two versions of the lower half of a giant face. These may be devils, demons, or goblins. The lower version is slightly larger. He has long hair, beard, and mustache. His mouth is open and his teeth are visible, biting, clasping, or possibly eating the limp nude corpse, whose legs and arms dangle in front of the giant's chin.

A limp nude corpse of indeterminate gender is being bitten by or clasped in the teeth of the demon lower on the page. The corpse is facing up, has long hair, its head is bent back, its arms and legs are dangling, and crossed at the ankles in front of the demon's chin.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a mounted knight in armor rides away from a woman who walks behind and to the left of him. The knight appears to be wearing a helmet. His bent right leg is visible, as is his right arm, which is at his side. The horse's right foreleg and left hind leg are raised and bent. The woman has long hair and her hands are clasped at her breast in a gesture of supplication or prayer. Above and to the left of the woman are faint indications of a building, possibly and fort or castle, in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a mounted knight in armor rides away from a woman who kneels behind and to the left of him. He appears to be wearing a helmet. His bent right leg is visible, as is his right arm, which is at his side.
The knight is mounted on a horse, which faces right and is walking away from the woman. The horse's right foreleg and left hind leg are raised and bent.
To the left and behind the knight, a gowned woman walks, facing the knight. She has long hair and her hands are clasped at her breast in a gesture of supplication or prayer.
Above and to the left of the woman are faint indications of a building, perhaps a fort or castle, in the background.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 9 in both versions. The lines inscribed below this emblem drawing, beginning "Ah luckless babe born under cruel star", may serve as a caption. See also Object 89.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a young male strides, with legs spread, from left to right. He wears tights or a combination of breeches and a shirt. His hair is curly. He faces to the right. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is raised vertically but slightly bent at the elbow. He holds a hat in his raised right hand. To the right of his face is a (nude and male?) human figure, perhaps an infant, child, cherub, or putto, hovering (flying?) in mid-air. We see this figure from the back, but with his head twisted back to the left. His legs are spread, as though fleeing from the youth with the hat, who may be pursuing him. The hovering figure has his left arm extended horizontally and his right arm extended at 45 degrees. Below, on the ground, in the right corner of the emblem, is a second diminutive figure of uncertain gender. He or she may be dead and lies face-down, with the right leg extended and arms extended horizontally in a cruciform position. His or her hair is long. There are leafy trees in the background of the emblem. In the upper left of the page is a face, drawn in profile, facing left, and with curly hair. This might be Robert Blake. Diagonal pen strokes (efforts at deletion?) cover the profile.

component.illusobjdesc: Leafy trees fill the background of the central emblem.

In the central emblem, a young male strides, with legs spread, from left to right. He wears tights--or a combination of breeches and a shirt. His hair is curly. He faces to the right. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is raised vertically but slightly bent at the elbow. He holds a hat in his raised right hand. He may be pursuing, and attempting to kill or capture, the flying figure to the right.

To the right of his face is a (nude and male?) human figure, perhaps an infant, child, cherub, or putto, hovering (flying?) in mid-air. We see this figure from the back, but with his head twisted back to the left. His legs are spread, as though fleeing from the youth with the hat, who may be pursuing him. The hovering figure has his left arm extended horizontally and his right arm extended at 45 degrees.

A diminutive figure of uncertain gender lies on the ground below the hovering figure. He or she may be dead and lies face-down, with the right leg extended and arms extended horizontally in a cruciform position. His or her hair is long.
In the upper left of the page is a face, drawn in profile, facing left, and with curly hair. This may be Robert Blake. Diagonal pen strokes (efforts at deletion?) cover the profile.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a male, perhaps Job, sits facing forward, surrounded by four men, two on each side. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, and his knees are prominent. His head appears to be bent back so that he faces upward. His arms are extended at his side with the palms facing the viewer. The posture suggests despair. The four males surrounding the central figure all sit or kneel, and all appear to be robed. The figure in the left foreground faces left and has his right arm raised horizontally and bent so that it is pointing at the central figure. Only part of the head of the figure in the left background is visible. The figure in the right foreground faces right and has curly hair and a beard. His right arm is raised horizontally and bent at a right angle, so that he points upward. His left arm is at his side, but bent upward so that it points at the central figure. Only part of the head and body of the figure in the right background is visible. These four surrounding figures may be Job's accusers. Lines above the figures may represent a stormy, cloudy sky. Alternatively, these lines may indicate the rocks above a cave in which the figures sit.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a male, perhaps Job, sits facing forward, surrounded by four men, two on each side. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, and his knees are prominent. His head appears to be bent back so that he faces upward. His arms are extended at his side with the palms facing the viewer. The posture suggests despair.

Four males surround the central figure, two on the left and two on the right. They all sit or kneel, and all appear to be robed. The figure in the left foreground faces left and has his right arm raised horizontally and bent so that it is pointing at the central figure. Only part of the head of the figure in the left background is visible. The figure in the right foreground faces right and has curly hair and a beard. His right arm is raised horizontally and bent at a right angle, so that he points upward. His left arm is at his side, but bent upward so that it points at the central figure. Only part of the head and body of the figure in the right background is visible. These figures may be accusers. If the central figure in Job, then these supposed friends and accusers are Elihu, Zophar, Eliphaz, and Bildad.
Lines above the figures may represent a stormy, cloudy sky. Alternatively, these lines may indicate the rocks above a cave in which the figures sit.

objnote.p: The lines inscribed below the central emblem design, "Every thing that grows / Holds in perfection but a little", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a gowned female emerges from an open blossom, possibly an anemone. She faces forward, though most of her lower body is concealed by the blossom; her hair is long and her arms are raised at 135 degrees with palms up. She looks down at the male figure below her, over whom she appears to be rising. The male figure is also emerging from the blossom so that only his upper body is visible. He faces forward and appears to be lying with his upper body raised and supported by his extended arms so that his body is bending backward. His head is bent back and twisted up and to the right so that he is looking at the female figure above him. There may be trees in the background on the left. In the upper left corner of the page, a male head is drawn in left profile. He has long curly hair and a curly beard. To the right of the head in profile are detail drawings of three pairs of closed lips.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a gowned female emerges from an open blossom. She faces forward, though most of her lower body is concealed by the blossom; her hair is long and her arms are raised at 135 degrees with palms up. She looks down at the male figure below her, over whom she appears to be rising.

Below the rising female is a male figure, also emerging from the blossom so that only his upper body is visible. He faces forward and appears to be lying with his upper body raised and supported by his extended arms so that his body is bending backward. His head is bent back and twisted up and to the right so that he is looking at the female figure above him.
The two human forms in the central emblem emerge from an open blossom, possibly an anemone.
In the upper left corner of the page, a male head is drawn in left profile. He has long curly hair and a curly beard.
To the right of the head in profile are detail drawings of three pairs of closed lips.
There may be trees in the background of the central emblem on the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure, perhaps female, sits facing right, toward a male kneeling before her. Her right arm is visible at her side and her head is bent down. She may be gowned. The male kneels on his left knee with his right leg bent and drawn up. His left arm is at his side and his right arm is extended horizontally toward the seated woman. To the left of the seated woman, a figure, perhaps male, stands facing left, turned away from the seated and kneeling figures. The standing figure's head is slightly lowered so that he faces down, and his left arm is bent upward so that his hand is either on his face or beside his head. He may be walking to the left. There may be clouds in the sky above the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure, perhaps female, sits facing right, toward a male kneeling before her. Her right arm is visible at her side and her head is bent down. She may be gowned.

To the right of the seated female figure and facing her, a male kneels on his left knee with his right leg bent and drawn up. His left arm is at his side and his right arm is extended horizontally toward the seated woman.

To the left of the seated woman, a figure, perhaps male, stands facing left, turned away from the seated and kneeling figures. The standing figure's head is slightly lowered so that he faces down, and his left arm is bent upward so that his hand is either on his face or beside his head. He may be walking to the left.
There may be clouds in the sky above the figures in the central emblem.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The trunk of a tree extends up the left side of the central emblem. At the top of the emblem, barren branches arch out over the cage that hangs on a rope or chain from one of the branches. Inside the cage huddles a contracted figure, possibly a child, perhaps sitting cross-legged with its head on its hands. Above the cage and below the main branch, what may be a bird hovers with wings spread.

component.illusobjdesc: The trunk of a tree extends up the left side of the central emblem. At the top of the emblem, leafless branches arch out over the cage that hangs from one of the branches.
Suspended from one of the tree branches is a cage, in which a human figure is huddled. The cage is suspended on a rope or chain attached to its roof. The cage is a prison or cell for the figure.
Inside the cage huddles a contracted figure, possibly a child, perhaps sitting cross-legged with its head on its hands. The figure's right knee is prominent. The figure's posture suggests despair.
Above the cage and below the main branch, what may be a bird flies with wings spread.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a crowned(?), bearded, and robed male figure stands facing right. His right arm is at his side, and his left arm is raised horizontally, holding a raised sword, staff, or stick toward two figures who appear to be retreating from him. If indeed he is crowned, this may be a king. To the right of the bearded man, a gowned woman(?) stands facing forward with her head turned left so that she is looking back toward the bearded man. Her arms are bent upward, with palms out. To the right of the female stands a male(?), facing right, who appears to be turning away from the bearded man. His arms are perhaps crossed at his chest. He may be walking to the right, right foot on tiptoe. Behind the figures leafy trees are visible, two of the trunks of which can be seen between the figures. There may be clouds upper left and right in the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a crowned(?) and robed male figure stands facing right. His right arm is at his side, and his left arm is raised horizontally, holding a raised sword, staff, or stick toward two figures who appear to be retreating from him. if indeed crowned, this may be a king.
To the right of the bearded man, a gowned woman(?) stands facing forward with her head turned left so that she is looking back toward the bearded man. Her arms are bent upward, with palms out.

To the right of the female stands a male(?), facing right, who appears to be turning away from the bearded man. His arms are perhaps crossed at his chest. He may be walking to the right, right foot on tiptoe.
Behind the figures leafy trees are visible, two of the trunks of which can be seen between the figures.
There may be clouds in the sky above the trees, upper left and right.

objnote.p: The central design is related to (but is not a direct preliminary for) *Europe a Prophecy*, Bentley Plate 10.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; her posture indicates pain or despair, possibly indicative of disease. In the lower left corner of the central emblem, a woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man to the left and behind her. Her hair is long, her right leg is bent, and her right arm is at her side. Her limp posture suggests despair and perhaps pain and disease. Behind her, a curly-haired male sits in profile against the lower left margin of the central emblem, facing right and down. He perhaps holds the woman to the right with his right arm. On a doorstep to the right of the central woman in the emblem, another woman also kneels, facing forward and right with her head bent back. Her body is limp, perhaps with disease and pain, and her right arm dangles. She is being held below her breasts by a gowned and seated female(?) figure behind her, who is facing forward. The background building includes a doorway and a pillar or pilaster left of the door. The sky upper left may be cloudy and stormy, perhaps including diagonal lines of rain. Below the central emblem, an enlarged detail—head, upper arms, and breasts—of the emblem's central figure is drawn. She faces right with her head bent back and facing up, long hair hanging down. At least her right arm is raised vertically.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; like her companions, her posture indicates pain or despair, possibly indicative of disease.

In the lower left corner of the central emblem, a woman sits on the ground, facing right, with her upper body propped up by the man to the left and behind her. Her hair is long, her right leg is bent, and her right arm is at her side. Her limp posture suggests despair and perhaps pain (from disease?).
A curly-haired male sits in profile against the lower left margin of the central emblem, facing right and down. He perhaps holds the woman to the right with his right arm.

On a doorstep to the right of the central woman in the emblem, another woman also kneels, facing right with her head bent back. Her body is limp, perhaps with disease and pain, and her right arm dangles. She may wear a gown or skirt and her breasts are clearly pictured. She is being held by the seated figure behind her.
A gowned female(?) is seated on a doorstep, facing forward, holding the body of the limp woman across her lap who kneels in front of her. She holds the woman's chest just below her breasts.
The two rightmost figures in the central emblem are seated on the doorstep of a building, the door and a pillar or pilaster of which are faintly visible behind the figures.
The sky upper left in the central emblem appears to be cloudy and stormy, possibly with diagonal lines of rain.

Below the central emblem, an enlarged detail—head, upper arms, and breasts—of the emblem's central figure is drawn. She faces right with her head bent back and facing up, long hair hanging down. At least her right arm is raised vertically.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a large number of soldiers are engaged in fighting. Figures on the left appear to be climbing out of a ship to attack figures on the right. At least one soldier on the left and one on the right can be seen with arms raised, holding swords. Elevated above the mass of fighting soldiers, a male figure stands with legs together on the prow of the ship. His arms are raised horizontally; in his right hand he holds a sword, in his left a shield. This may be Caesar, landing in Britain. Directly to the left and below the elevated figure, what appears to be a dead or dying soldier hangs over the side of the ship. Only his upper body is visible, upside down and seen from behind. His arms may be dangling. To the left of the dead or dying figure, another soldier leaps overboard, facing forward. His right arm is raised across his body and holding a standard with the form of an eagle at its top. The soldier's mouth is open. To the right and below the elevated figure, a soldier strides with right leg forward, legs spread. His body faces forward, his head is bent back possibly with mouth open, and he looks up at the elevated figure. His right arm reaches downward across his body, possibly holding a sword. He holds a shield in his left hand. On the right side of the design, cut off by the border of the emblem, a portion of an elephant is visible, facing left. In its curled trunk it holds a trumpet. On the right side of the emblem, behind the trumpet held by the elephant and above the heads of several soldiers is perhaps a rectangular flag. A few lines above and below the flag might represent cliffs above the shore where the soldiers are landing.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a large number of soldiers is engaged in fighting. Figures on the left appear to be climbing out of a ship to attack figures on the right. At least one soldier on the left and one on the right can be seen with arms raised, holding swords. Soldiers in the background on the right may be holding spears rising diagonally right to left.

In the center of the emblem, elevated above the mass of fighting soldiers, a male figure stands with legs together on the prow of the ship. His arms are spread horizontally; in his right hand he holds a sword, in his left a shield. This may be Caesar, landing in Britain.

Directly to the left and below the elevated figure, what appears to be a dead or dying soldier hangs over the side of the ship. Only his upper body is visible, upside down and seen from behind. His arms may be dangling, but the drawing here is indeterminate.

To the left of the dead or dying figure, another soldier leaps overboard, facing forward. His right arm is raised across his body and holding a pole (or "standard") with the form of an eagle at its top. The soldier's mouth may be open.

To the right and below the elevated figure, a soldier strides with right leg forward, legs spread. His body faces forward, his head is bent back with mouth open, and he looks up at the elevated figure. His right arm reaches downward across his body, possibly holding a sword. He holds a shield in his left hand.
On the right side of the design, cut off by the border of the emblem, a portion of an elephant is visible, facing left. In its curled trunk it holds a trumpet.
Several soldiers disembark from a ship, its bow on the right.
On the right side of the emblem, behind the trumpet held by the elephant and above the heads of several soldiers is perhaps a rectangular flag.

The subject of the design may be Caesar landing on the shore of Britain, with cliffs (of Dover?) rising on the right behind the rectangular flag. The beach may be sandy, with some stones lower center.

objnote.p: The lines inscribed below the design, "The drift of hollow states hard to / be spelld Milton", may serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the bottom of the central emblem lies a supine figure, perhaps dead or dying, of indeterminate gender. It is facing up, the left arm visible at its side. Four figures are arranged around the supine figure. Behind its leg, two figures appear to prostrate themselves side by side with heads facing forward, toward the supine figure. Standing at the head of the supine figure are two other figures, also side by side, with heads bent downward, looking at the supine figure. The standing figures appear to be robed, with arms at sides. On the left side of the emblem, to the left of the prostrate figures, is an indistinct figure, only the extended (left?) leg, head, and perhaps bent left arm visible. This figure may be getting struck by lightning, which descends from a cloud in the upper left of the emblem. It is unclear what the rectangular object above the prostrate figures might be, but there could be a human figure within the rectangle, seated and facing left. There may be a pillar, post, or tree trunk in the upper right with a hill or mountain behind.

component.illusobjdesc: At the bottom of the central emblem lies a supine figure, perhaps dead or dying, of indeterminate gender. It is facing up, the left arm visible at its side.

Four figures are arranged around the supine figure. Behind its leg, two figures appear to prostrate themselves side by side with heads facing forward, toward the supine figure. Their features are largely indeterminate. Standing at the head of the supine figure are two other figures, also side by side, with heads bent downward, looking at the supine figure. The standing figures appear to be robed, with arms at sides.

On the left side of the emblem, to the left of the prostrate figures, is an indistinct figure, only the extended (left?) leg, head, and perhaps bent left arm of whom are visible. This figure may be getting struck by lightning.
It is unclear what the rectangular object above the prostrate figures on the left might be, but there could be a human figure within the rectangle, seated and facing left.
In the upper left corner of the emblem there appears to be a cloud and perhaps a lightning bold descending from it. The lightning may be striking the indistinct left-most figure.
There may be a pillar, post, or tree trunk upper right, with a hill or distant mountain behind.

objnote.p: The drawing is a preliminary sketch for *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 3.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The main image of the page, slightly below and left of center, features a young nude woman who kneels on the ground and leans to the left with her arms crossed in front of her and her hands over her breasts. Her hair appears to be long. She appears to be kissing a much smaller figure, probably also female. This second nude figure is seen from behind; her arms are extended horizontally. Her right leg is bent at the knee in a dance-like posture and her left leg seems poised on the flower of what may be a marigold. The kneeling figure is probably Oothoon, the smaller figure probably the "nymph" who personifies the marigold, as the context of the etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion indicates. To the kneeling figure's right are traces of an erased drawing depicting a figure standing acing left with arm bent and features expressive of woe or jealousy (corners of mouth turned down). A few strands of long hair drift right of the figure's head. This may be an alternative position for Oothoon, looking down on the flower and nymph. Beside her a straight tree is loosely entwined by a vine. Diagonal lines upper left, rising from left to right, are probably beams of light.

component.illusobjdesc: A young nude woman kneels on the ground and leans to the right with her arms crossed in front of her and her hands over her breasts. Her hair appears to be long and she appears to be kissing a much smaller figure, probably also female. The kneeling figure may be Oothoon, as the context of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion indicates.

A nude figure, probably female, is seen from the back. She hovers in the air, with her left foot poised just above a flower from which she may be rising. Her arms are extended horizontally and her right knee bent forward. This dance-like posture includes a gracefully twisted torso. She appears to be kissing the much larger female on the right. If so, then her head may be bent back so that she is looking up. This small figure may be the "nymph" who personifies the marigold flower below her.
Although not distinctly drawn, the petals of a flower, perhaps a marigold, are visible below the foot of the smaller figure.

To the right of the kneeling figure are traces of an erased drawing depicting a figure with long hair standing with left arm bent and features expressive of woe or jealousy (corners of mouth turned down). This may be an alternative position for Oothoon, later sketched below and to the left. She faces forward and left and looks down toward the flower and nymph.
To the right and slightly behind the male figure is the trunk of a straight tree, loosely entwined by a vine.
Beams of light, possibly indicating a sunrise or sunset, rise from the lower left corner of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a gowned, long-haired female hovers horizontally over an outstretched male. She is facing right and down. Her arms are raised and bent at the elbow, her hands beside her head, the left hand higher than the right. Directly below her, a male(?) figure lies outstretched on his left hip with his torso twisted so that his head is to the right and facing down. His right arm is extended and his left leg is drawn up. He may be sleeping or dead. Beside his right elbow is an object that might be a hat or stone. Diagonal lines above and below the hovering figure hint at beams of light.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned, long-haired female hovers horizontally over an outstretched male. She is facing right and down. Her arms are raised and bent at the elbow, her hands beside her head, the left hand higher than the right.

Below the hovering female, a male(?) figure lies outstretched on his left hip with his torso twisted so that his head is to the right and facing down. His right arm is extended and his left leg is drawn up. He may be sleeping or dead. Beside his right elbow is an object that might be a hat or stone.
Beside the male figure's right elbow is an object that might be a hat or stone. Diagonal lines above and below the hovering figure hint at beams of light.

objnote.p: Blake used a very similar group of figures lower left on the title page of *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 2. The lines inscribed in pencil below this emblem drawing, "A fairy vision of some gay / creatures of the rainbow live", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, four dancing figures form a rough circle in the sky with clouds around them. A few lines hint at a rainbow behind the figures. A female figure, the lowest of four figures in the circle, strides or leaps energetically to the left. She appears to be nude, but a piece of gown may be trailing from her left leg. In both raised hands, she holds the ends of two separate pieces of what seems to be some kind of cloth, perhaps a scarf, which connects her to two other dancers in the circle. Her hair may be drawn up in a bun. Her lower body is facing left, her left leg is extended backwards, and her upper body is twisted so that her head is facing right, looking back over her right shoulder. She balances on what might be a cloud. A female figure strides or leaps in midair above and to the left of the lowest of the four figures. Her torso is horizontal and she faces upward, her head thrown back. Like the figure below her, her arms are extended and raised slightly above the horizontal. Her right leg extends behind her and what might be part of a gown descends from her waist along her right leg. She is connected to the figure below her by the scarf-like cloth, which she holds in her right hand. The most indistinct of the four figures, the topmost, hovers in midair with its head toward the viewer or facing left and its arms extended horizontally. What might be a long, flowing drapery extends behind and to the left of the figure. Its right hand is connected to the upward reaching left hand of the horizontal female below it, and its left hand may be connected by another scarf-like cloth to the right-most figure in the circle. The right-most figure strides or leaps in midair, its head thrown back and facing up, its right leg extended backward. Its right arm is raised vertically and it may be grabbing a scarf that is trailing from the extended left hand of the top-most figure. Its left arm is extended downward to connect with the right hand of (or a scarf-like cloth held by) the lower-most female.

component.illusobjdesc: Four dancing figures form a rough circle against what might be a rainbow. A female figure, the lowest of four figures in the circle, strides or leaps energetically to the left. She appears to be nude, but a piece of gown may be trailing from her left leg. In both horizontally extended hands, she holds the ends of two separate pieces of what seems to be some kind of cloth--perhaps a scarf--which connects her to two other dancers in the circle. Her hair may be drawn up in a bun. Her lower body is facing left, her left leg is extended backwards, and her upper body is twisted so that her head is facing right, looking back over her right shoulder. She balances on what might be a cloud.

Four dancing figures form a rough circle against what might be a rainbow. A female figure strides or leaps in midair above and to the left of the lowest of the four figures. Her torso is horizontal and she faces upward, her head thrown back. Like the figure below her, her arms are extended and raised slightly above the horizontal (relative to her body, but nearly vertical otherwise). Her right leg extends behind her and what might be part of a gown descends from her waist along her right leg. She is connected to the figure below her by the scarf-like cloth, which she holds in her right hand.

Four dancing figures form a rough circle against what might be a rainbow. The most indistinct of the four figures, the topmost, hovers in midair with its head toward the viewer or facing left and its arms extended horizontally. What might be a long, flowing drapery extends behind and to the left of the figure. Its right hand is connected to the upward reaching left hand of the horizontal female below it, and its left hand may be connected by another scarf-like cloth to the right-most figure in the circle.

Four dancing figures form a rough circle against what might be a rainbow. The right-most figure strides or leaps in midair, its head thrown backward and facing up, its right leg extended backward. Its right arm is raised vertically and it may be grabbing a scarf that is trailing from the extended left hand of the top-most figure. Its left arm is extended downward to connect with the right hand of (or a scarf-like cloth held by) the lower-most female.
The curved lines below the lower-most figure suggest that she is standing on a cloud. The dark areas in each corner of the emblem may also be clouds.

The figures dance in a roughly circular formation against what might be a section of a rainbow, indicated by light diagonal lines descending from left to right in the space between clouds where the figures appear.

objnote.p: The drawing is very similar to, but probably executed later than, a wash drawing by Blake, *A Soul at the Door of Paradise*, Butlin 131 recto.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a robed or gowned figure, probably female, floats before a doorway on a cloud, facing away from the viewer. The figure's arms are bent upward so that the forearms and hands may be reaching toward two or more barely discernible figures on the within the doorway. The scene may take place at the entry to heaven.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a robed or gowned figure, probably female, floats before a doorway on a cloud, facing away from the viewer. The figure's arms are bent upward so that the forearms and hands may be reaching toward two or more barely discernible figures on the within the doorway. The figure's hair is long.

Within the doorway the heads and upper bodies of at least two figures can be discerned, one on each side of the central figure. They probably face forward to greet the central figure. Just above the head of the central figure is a round form that may be either an alternative position for the head of the central figure or the head of a third figure meeting the central figure.
The central figure floats on a cloud and stands before an open doorway. The scene may unfold at the entry to heaven.

objnote.p: The drawing is a preliminary sketch for *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 6.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude female lies supine on a cloud. Her right arm is extended vertically relative to her body. Her long hair can be seen above her right forearm. Her head is thrown back and her belly exposed. Her legs are spread apart and bent back sharply at the knees so we see only her upper legs. This posture suggests erotic (or at least highly emotional) abandon. Above her hovers a large bird, probably an eagle.
