The bird seems to descend upon the female, with its beak touching her torso between the stomach and breasts. The eagle may be biting the woman or even eating at her flesh. Above the female's head is another cloud or an extension of the cloud on which the female lies. The female is probably Oothoon, as the context of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion indicates. Some curving lines below the cloud on which the woman lies difficult to decipher; they may be more clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female lies supine on a cloud. Her right arm is extended horizontally to the left (but raised vertically relative to her body). Her long hair can be seen above her right forearm. Her head is thrown back and her belly exposed. Her legs are spread apart and bent back sharply at the knees so we see only her upper legs. This posture suggests erotic (or at least highly emotional) abandon. She is probably Oothoon, as the context of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion indicates.

A large bird, probably an eagle hovers over the supine female. Its wings extend horizontally; its head faces downward toward the woman. The bird's beak touches her torso; its prominent tail is slightly forked. The eagle may be biting the woman or even eating at her flesh.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned figure, perhaps female, sits before a bed on which two figures are lying. The seated figure faces right, with her head down, perhaps kissing an infant that she holds in her bent right arm. Only the head and left arm of the infant are visible. A rectangular object to the right might be the infant's cradle or, if the infant is dead, a small coffin. Behind the seated woman, two figures lie side by side on a bed, facing up. Only the head of the rear figure is visible, while the left arm is visible at the side of the figure nearest the seated woman. The supine figures may be sick, dying, or dead. Parallel diagonal lines behind and above the bed might indicate curtains. On the upper portion of the page are drawn two pairs of closed lips, one nearly centered, the other to the right and slightly lower.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned figure, perhaps female, sits before a bed on which two figures are lying. The seated figure faces right, with her head down, perhaps kissing an infant that she holds in her bent right arm. The facial features of the seated figure are indeterminate.
The seated woman holds and perhaps kisses an infant, only the head and left arm of which are visible. If the rectangular object to the right is a small coffin, the infant may be dead.

Behind the seated woman, two figures lie side by side, facing up on a bed. Only the head of the rear figure is visible, while the left arm is visible at the side of the figure nearest the seated woman. The supine figures may be sick, dying, or dead.
The woman beside the bed is seated on a chair or stool.
The two supine figures lie on a bed, their heads supported by pillows.
A rectangular object to the right of the woman and infant might be the infant's cradle or, if the infant is dead, a small coffin.
Parallel diagonal lines behind and above the bed might indicate curtains.
On the upper portion of the page are drawn two pairs of closed lips, one nearly centered, the other to the right and slightly lower.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 10 in both versions. The text written in pencil below this drawing, "My son My son", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the right of the central emblem, a youthful (male?) figure strides to the right. His body is twisted and he may be facing to the left, toward a seated male figure. The youth's left arm is raised horizontally and he may be pointing toward the seated figure. The youth's right arm is raised vertically; he grasps what may be a spear or dart in his right hand. He may be about to throw his weapon at the seated figure, whose right leg is bent at the knee, his left leg extended to the right. The seated figure is bearded; he may be old. His right arm is bent at the elbow and he props his head on his right hand, a posture traditionally indicative of melancholy. His left arm is raised horizontally, as if to ward off the youthful figure. He is seated on what might be some large stairs, part of a building behind and to the left of him. The inscribed caption, "My son My son", indicates that the figures are father (left) and son.

component.illusobjdesc: The seated figure in the central emblem is sitting on what may be some large stairs, part of a building behind and to the left of him. Vertical lines above the stairs on the left may be a door or pillars.

On the right of the central emblem, a youthful male figure strides to the right. His body is twisted and he may be facing to the left, toward a seated (male?) figure. The youth's left arm is raised horizontally and he may be pointing toward the seated figure. The youth's right arm is raised vertically; he grasps what may be a spear in his right hand. He may be about to throw his weapon at the seated figure. The inscribed caption, "My son My son", indicates that the figures are father (left) and son.

To the left of the youth is a seated figure, whose right leg is bent at the knee, his left leg extended to the right. The seated figure is bearded; he may be old. His right arm is bent at the elbow and he props his head on his right hand, a posture traditionally indicative of melancholy. His left arm is raised horizontally, as if to ward off the youthful figure. The inscribed caption, "My son My son", indicates that the figures are father (left) and son.

objnote.p: Except for the clouds, this pencil drawing is very similar to Blake's planographic transfer print, "Charity". In the print, the central adult is clearly female; that may not be the case in this Notebook sketch.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a robed figure faces forward, standing or walking on a cloud, leading several children, perhaps two to the left and three to the right. The adult is gowned with a belt just below the chest. The adult figure's head is turned slightly down and to the left. She or he holds the hand of at least the child to the left; both arms are at the adult's side. The identity of the adult is uncertain; this may be Christ leding children or a female, such as the children's mother.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a robed figure faces forward, standing or walking on a cloud, leading several children, perhaps two to the left and three to the right. The adult is gowned with a belt just below the chest. The adult figure's head is turned slightly down and to the left. She or he holds the hand of at least the child to the left; both arms are at the adult's side. The identity of the adult is uncertain; this may be Christ leading children or a female, such as the children's mother.

Children stand on each side of the adult figure, two to the left and two or three to the right. At least the child closest to the adult on the left raises its arm and holds the adult's hand. The two frontmost children on the right may be embracing.
The adult and the children are standing or walking on a cloud.

objnote.p: The text written in pencil below the central drawing, "As Daphne was root bound", serves as a caption. See also Object 2.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, A figure is seen from behind, bending slightly forward at the waist with legs crossed. This is probably Daphne (as the caption indicates) being transformed into a laurel tree, as in the classical myth. Her body appears to be twisted, with her head bent back and facing up. She is represented in the process of vegetating; roots can be seen extending from her feet, and her arms are raised vertically, terminating in multiple leafy branches that hang down around her. In the upper left portion of the page, beneath text in pen and ink, is a bare foot with the toes facing forward. The lines right of the central emblem might be a bent right arm seen from behind. For another drawing of Daphne, see object 2.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure is seen from behind, bending slightly forward at the waist with legs crossed. This is probably Daphne (as the caption indicates) being transformed into a laurel tree, as in the classical myth. Her body appears to be twisted, with her head bent back and facing up. She is represented in the process of vegetating; roots can be seen extending from her feet, and her arms are raised vertically, terminating in multiple leafy branches that hang down around her.
In the upper left of the page, beneath text in pen and ink, is a bare foot with the toes facing forward.
Lines right of the central emblem might be a bent right arm seen from behind.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure lies face up on a bed, most likely a sickbed, since the figure is surrounded by five people who lean attentively toward it. Its head is supported by a pillow and in its left hand seems to be a book. The figure closest to the head of the invalid bends forward at the waist, facing right, looking at the face of the invalid. The bending figure's right arm is also bent and raised toward its face. The right arm of another figure is also seen. The heads of the figures descend in height from the upper left to the invalid's head in the lower right. A few diagonal lines above the figures may be bed curtains. Lightly sketched lines below the figure in the bed may be a kneeling figure hunched over to the right. This figure may have been part of an earlier version of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure lies face up on a bed, most likely a sickbed, since the figure is surrounded by five people who lean attentively toward it. This figure may be dead or dying. In its left hand seems to be a book.

Gathered at the sickbed is a group of five figures, all seemingly gowned or in robes. The figure closest to the head of the invalid bends forward at the waist, facing right, looking at the face of the invalid. The bending figure's right arm is also bent and raised toward its face. The right arm of another figure is also seen. The heads of the figures descend in height from the upper left to the invalid's head in the lower right.
The invalid lies on a bed, its head supported by a pillow.
A few diagonal lines above the figures may be bed curtains.
Lightly sketched lines below the figure in the bed may be a kneeling figure hunched over to the right. This figure may have been part of an earlier version of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nearly centered on the page is the armless, headless, muscular upper body of a male, seen from behind. To the right of the torso design is an extended finger, pointing to the right. Near the upper right corner of the page is an indeterminate design, perhaps a finger.

component.illusobjdesc: Nearly centered on the page is the armless, headless, muscular upper body of a male, seen from behind.
Near the upper right corner of the page is an indeterminate design, perhaps a finger.
To the right of the torso design is an extended finger, pointing to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central emblem depicts a room with what may be a family in it. In the background a figure lies face up on a low bed or on a pillow and blanket placed on the floor. It may be sick or dying, given the postures of the figures beside it. In the foreground and seen from behind, a gowned female kneels near the head of the supine figure. She kneels on just her left knee, leaning over her raised right knee. Her body is twisted to the right as she turns to look at a male entering through the door. At the foot of the bedding and beside the open door stands a gowned female(?) child, facing forward. Her hands are on her face in a gesture of grief or despair. A robed male, possibly wearing a turban, enters the room through an open doorway. He faces left and holds a doll(?) upside down by its legs in his left hand. In his left arm he clutches an indeterminate object, perhaps another doll.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure lies face up on a low bed or on the floor. It may be sick or dying, given the postures of the figures beside it.

In the foreground and seen from behind, a gowned female kneels near the head of the supine figure. She kneels on just her left knee, leaning over her raised right knee. Her body is twisted to the right as she turns to look at the male entering through the door. She may be wearing a turban-like hat.
At the foot of the pallet and beside the open door stands a gowned female(?) child, facing forward. Her hands are on her face in a gesture of grief or despair.

On the right side of the central emblem, a robed male wearing a turban enters the room through an open doorway. He faces left and holds a doll upside down by its legs in his left hand. In his left arm he clutches another indeterminate object, perhaps another doll.
The four figures here may constitute a family.
The scene probably takes place in a room.
The supine figure lies on a low bed or on a blanket and pillow placed on the floor.
The male figure enters through an open doorway on the right.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 11 in both versions.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page a long ladder reaches from the surface of the earth upward and to the right, ending at a thin, crescent moon. A small figure has just begun to climb the ladder, with the left leg bent at the knee so as to place the left foot on the first rung of the ladder, and the right foot still on the earth. At least one of this figure's arms is raised horizontally, reaching toward or holding the ladder. To the left are two standing figures, both of whom appear to be facing to the right and looking at the figure climbing the ladder. In the lower right of the page is the head and shoulders of what appears to be a man, with features heavily penciled over so that they are hardly discernible.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central image a long ladder extends from the earth upward and to the right.
The ladder terminates at a thin, crescent moon.

A small figure has just begun to climb the ladder, with the left leg bent at the knee so as to place the left foot on the first rung of the ladder, and the right foot still on the earth. At least one of this figure's arms is raised horizontally, reaching toward or holding the ladder.
To this figure's left are two standing figures, both of whom appear to be facing to the right and looking at the figure climbing the ladder.
In the lower right of the page is the head and shoulders of what appears to be a man, with features heavily penciled over, so that they are hardly discernible.

objnote.p: The drawing is a preliminary sketch for *Parental Affection*, a water color by Blake discovered in 2010.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a man and woman stand outside an arched door, embracing a boy and a girl. The man is bearded, has curly hair, and appears to be wearing a long coat or gown. He faces right, his head bent down and looking at the girl whom he embraces. The girl's head is bent back, looking up at him. Her left arm is raised to the man's right shoulder and her left leg is extended backward. Behind and to the right of the man, a long-haired woman, also facing right, embraces and perhaps kisses the boy. Her head is also bent downward. The curly-haired boy mirrors the girl's posture as he embraces the woman. His left arm is also raised, his head is bent back, and he may be kissing the woman. His left leg is extended backward and a garment swirls at his knee. In the background, to the right of the embracing figures, are perhaps two trees. The building may include a pillar or pilaster on its right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a man and woman stand outside a Gothic door, embracing a boy and a girl. The man is bearded, has curly hair, and appears to be wearing a long coat or gown. He faces right, his head bent down and looking at the girl whom he embraces.
Behind and to the right of the man, a long-haired woman, also facing right, embraces and perhaps kisses the boy. Her head is also bent downward.
The man embraces a long-haired girl whose head is bent back, looking up at him. Her left arm is raised to the man's right shoulder and her left leg is extended backward, foot on tiptoe.

Behind and to the right of the girl, a curly-haired boy mirrors her posture as he embraces the woman. His left arm is also raised, his head is bent back, and he may be kissing the woman. His left leg is extended backward, foot on tiptoe, and a garment swirls at his knee.
This group of figures may be a family.

The embracing figures stand in front of a building, the arched doorway of which is visible behind and to the left of the man. The shape of the door suggests Gothic art. There may be a pillar or pilaster on the right corner of the building.
In the background, to the right of the embracing figures, are perhaps two trees.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem an old robed and bearded man stands facing right, leaning on a crutch, walking stick, or a staff that he holds in his right hand. His left arm is extended horizontally, palm facing the viewer, toward a spider(?) that hangs to his right, suspended from a vertical thread that descends from the top of the emblem. Alernatively, if the "thread" is part of the frame surrounding the design or one of the lines defining a room, then the creature could by a flying insect, such as a moth or butterfly.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem an old robed and bearded man stands facing right, leaning on a crutch, walking stick, or a staff that he holds in his right hand. His left arm is extended horizontally, palm facing the viewer, toward a spider(?) that hangs to his right.

The old man is looking at and has his arm extended toward what may be a spider hanging at about the height of the man's waist. The spider may be hanging from a vertical thread that descends from the top of the emblem. Alernatively, if the "thread" is part of the frame surrounding the design, or one of the lines defining a room, then the creature could by a flying insect, such as a moth or butterfly.
The lines surrounding the design may be a pictorial frame, but perhaps they indicate the walls of a room.

objnote.p: The central drawing is closely related to, and may be a preliminary sketch for, the title page to *Songs of Experience*, Bentley Plate 29.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, A young short-haired male (behind) and young gowned female (in front) with long hair bend over one or two dead(?) bodies laid out on a draped table, bed, or bier. Only the upper body of the male is visible. The two mourners are seen in profile facing right, holding their heads down and holding their hands to their faces in gestures of grief. The female stands with her weight on her left leg, her right leg extended behind, foot perhaps on tiptoe. They may be children of the dead couple. The scene may take place in a room.

component.illusobjdesc: A young short-haired male (behind) and young gowned female (in front) with long hair bend over one or two dead(?) bodies laid out on a draped table,bed, or bier. Only the upper body of the male is visible. The two mourners are seen in profile facing right, holding their heads down and holding their hands to their faces in gestures of grief. The female stands with her weight on her left leg, her right leg extended behind, foot perhaps on tiptoe. They may be children of the dead couple.

One or two dead(?) bodies, an old, bearded, gowned male (in front) and an indeterminate figure (behind), are laid out rigidly on a draped table, bed, or bier. The bodies are arranged horizontally with their heads resting on pillows at right. The visible left arm of the male is at his side. The figure behind the bearded male is only hinted at with a few lines perhaps defining a head.
One or two bodies are laid out on a draped table, bed, or bier. The heads rest on pillows at the right side of the emblem.
The scene may take place in a room defined by lines indicating walls, although these may only be a pictorial frame.

objnote.p: The drawing is closely related to, and may be a preliminary sketch for, *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*, Bentley Plate 24. See also Object 50.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bearded nude male, looking out at the viewer with an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls rightward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33).

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude male with long hair and beard, looking out at the viewer with his mouth open in an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls leftward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar (not mentioned in the text), king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33).
A muscular nude male crawls leftward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 18 in both versions. The lines of text written in pencil below this drawing, beginning, "I have said to corruption thou art...", serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a gowned figure of uncertain gender squats or sits, with legs drawn up and prominent knees, upon the earth. The figure, who faces forward with arms at side, has a scarf or hood over the head. A worm lies on the ground, encircling the figure and reaching upward in a loop on the right side of the figure. The background includes an arched entry to a dark cave and rocks above it. Some forms lower right might be stones or plants.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a gowned figure of uncertain gender squats or sits, with legs drawn up and prominent knees, upon the earth. The figure, who faces forward with arms at side, has a scarf or hood over the head.
A worm lies on the ground, encircling the seated figure and reaching upward in a loop on the right side of the figure.
The background includes the arched entry to a dark cave with rocks above.
The objects lower right may be stones or plants.

objnote.p: The word inscribed beneath the emblem design, "Murder", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left side of the central emblem, a male figure stands with legs spread beside a bed with a supine figure on it. The standing figure may be wearing a hat and cloak. His right arm reaches forward, possibly holding a dagger. Vertical and diagonal lines behind the bed suggest curtains and/or a background wall.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left side of the central emblem, a male figure stands with legs spread beside a bed with a supine figure on it. The standing figure may be wearing a hat and cloak. His right arm reaches forward, possibly holding a dagger. As the caption, "Murder", indicates, this figure is a murderer. He appears to be looking back to the left.

A supine figure lies facing up on a bed, its body covered by a blanket and its left arm at its side. Its head is supported by a pillow. The figure being or about to be murdered by the assassin standing at the bedside.
The supine figure lies beneath a blanket on a bed, its head supported by a pillow.
Vertical and diagonal lines behind the bed suggest curtains and perhaps the back wall of a room.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem is a group of naked dancers. The frontmost dancer is seen from behind, leaping to the left with its legs together and nearly horizontal, the left leg extended and the right leg bent at the knee. Its body is bent so that the upper body is vertical; the arms are raised and extended horizontally. Opposite the foremost dancer and facing forward is another dancing figure, leaning to the left, its upper body mirroring that of the foremost dancer, its arms raised and extended horizontally. Between the outstretched arms of the two central dancers are two smaller dancers. The one on the left leaps or hovers in a contrapposto position, its arms raised above its head and its hands together. Its head is bent back and it faces up. The smaller dancer on the right leaps to the left in a posture similar to that of the foremost dancer. The smaller dancer is also seen from behind, its body bent so that the upper body is vertical. Its left leg may be bent at the knee and its right leg may be extended. Unlike the foremost dancer, its arms are raised vertically and its head is bent backward and faces up. In the lower left of the page is the head of a young, curly-haired man, facing forward, wearing a large plummed hat and collar.

component.illusobjdesc: The frontmost dancer is seen from behind, leaping to the left with its legs together and nearly horizontal, the left leg extended and the right leg bent at the knee. Its body is bent so that the upper body is vertical; the arms are raised and extended horizontally.
Opposite the foremost dancer and facing forward is another dancing figure, leaning to the left, its upper body mirroring that of the foremost dancer, its arms raised and extended horizontally.

Between the outstretched arms of the two central dancers are two smaller dancers. The one on the left leaps or hovers in a contrapposto position, its arms raised above its head and its hands together. Its head is bent back and it faces up.

Between the outstretched arms of the two central dancers are two smaller dancers. The one on the right leaps to the left in a posture similar to that of the foremost dancer. The smaller dancer is also seen from behind, its body bent so that the upper body is vertical. Its left leg may be bent at the knee and its right leg may be extended. Unlike the foremost dancer, its arms are raised vertically and its head is bent backward and facing up.
In the lower left portion of the page is the head of a young, curly-haired man, facing forward, wearing a large plummed hat and collar.

objnote.p: The central drawing is related to, and may be a preliminary sketch for, *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*, Bentley Plate 24. See also Object 46.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male with long hair and beard, looking out at the viewer with his mouth open in an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls rightward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33). To the right of the crawling monarch are a few lines that might be the legs of a half-erased of a running or leaping animal.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with long hair, beard, and perhaps a crown, looking out at the viewer with his mouth open in an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls rightward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33).
A nude male crawls rightward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks.
To the right of the crawling monarch are a few lines that might be the legs of a half-erased running or leaping animal.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the foreground of the central emblem, a male figure stands in front of or strides away from an outstretched figure who may be dead. The standing figure is twisted so that it is facing left and looking down at the supine figure. The standing figure's hands are clutching his head in a gesture of despair. This may be Cain, and thus outstretched body may be Abel. His body is bent slightly backward and its arms may be raised vertically relative to its body. Curving lines right and left of the standing figure might be background clouds. Two vertical lines rising from the lower left corner of the design are probably part of the pictorial frame.

component.illusobjdesc: In the foreground of the central emblem, a male figure stands in front of or strides away from an outstretched figure who may be dead. The standing figure is twisted so that it is facing left and looking down at the supine figure. The standing figure's hands are clutching his head in a gesture of despair. This may be Cain.
Behind the standing figure is an outstretched body, perhaps dead. The body is bent slightly backward and its arms may be raised vertically relative to its body. This may be Abel.
Curving lines left and right of the standing figure may represent background clouds.

objnote.p: The slight sketch above the central drawing may be an early version of the design in *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 7.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a nude male figure stands facing forward with legs spread, right leg bent forward. His head is bent back, his right arm is extended horizontally, and his left arm is extended at 135 degrees, palm up. In his right hand he holds a dagger, with which he may have stabbed himself, suggested by the dark wound-like mark on his chest. Two lines below the figure's feet suggests a shadow. Above this emblem, a figure of indeterminate gender sits with knees drawn up to its upper chest in a very contracted posture. Its legs are probably crossed at the ankles. Its head appears bent forward and rests atop the knees. Above the contracted figure hovers what might be a gowned female, with body horizontal, head to the left, and with her right arm extended horizontally (but vertically relative to her body). Her left arm may be extended horizontally. In the etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion, the hovering figure is Oothoon and the contracted figure is probably Theotormon.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a nude male figure stands facing forward with legs spread, right leg bent forward. His left foot may be on tiptoe. His head is bent back, his right arm is extended horizontally, and his left arm is extended at 135 degrees, palm up. In his right hand he holds a dagger, with which he may have stabbed himself, suggested by the dark wound-like mark on his chest.
The figure in the central emblem holds a dagger, with which he may have stabbed himself, suggested by the dark wound-like mark on his chest.
The central figure's shadow extends from his feet to the right.

A figure of indeterminate gender sits with knees drawn up to its upper chest in a very contracted posture. Its legs are probably crossed at the ankles. Its head appears bent forward and rests atop the knees. In the etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion, this figure is probably Theotormon.

Above the contracted figure hovers what might be a gowned female, with body horizontal, head to the left, and with her right arm extended horizontally (but vertically relative to her body). Her left arm may be extended horizontally. In the etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion, the hovering figure is Oothoon.

objnote.p: The figures blowing a curled horn in the central design and also sketched lower left are very similar to, and may be preliminaries for, a figure upper left in *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 4.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, five figures, probably fairies, dance in a clockwise ring around a plant or flower. Each fairy leaps or strides with one leg extended backward and both arms raised at 135 degrees. Each fairy's body is twisted so that it holds the hands of the fairies adjacent to it in the circle. Sitting atop the plant or flower is a fairy facing forward with its right leg bent and crossed over its left knee; its left leg is dangling. Its upper body is twisted to the right and its right arm is bent and raised, holding to its mouth (and probably playing) a serpentine trumpet with one loop in it. To the right of the trumpet-blowing fairy in the central emblem is a crescent moon. In the lower left corner of the page is a detail of the trumpet-blowing fairy in the central emblem; it is also seated atop a plant or flower.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, five figures, probably fairies, dance in a clockwise ring around a plant or flower. Each fairy leaps or strides with one leg extended backward and both arms raised at 135 degrees. Each fairy's body is twisted so that it holds the hands of the fairies adjacent to it in the circle.

Sitting atop a plant or flower is a fairy facing forward with its right leg bent and crossed over its left knee; its left leg is dangling. Its upper body is twisted to the right and its right arm is bent and raised, holding to its mouth a serpentine trumpet with one loop in it.
The fairy holds to its mouth a serpentine trumpet with one loop in it.
The dancing fairies encircle the stem of a flower or plant with hanging leaves or branches. Atop this vegetation sits a trumpet-blowing fairy.
To the right of the trumpet-blowing fairy in the central emblem is a crescent moon.

In the lower left corner of the page is a detail of the trumpet-blowing fairy in the central emblem. It is sitting atop a plant or flower, facing forward with its right leg bent and crossed over its left knee; its left leg is dangling. Its upper body is twisted to the right and its right arm is raised, holding to its mouth a serpentine trumpet with one loop in it.
The fairy holds to its mouth a serpentine trumpet with one loop in it.
The fairy in the lower left corner of the page is seated atop a plant or flower.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 13 in both versions. The text written in pencil below this drawing, "Aged Ignorance", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left of the emblem sits a gowned old man wearing spectacles. He has a long beard and long hair. His eyes are closed or look sharply down. He may be blind or partly blind. His legs, with prominent knees, are crossed at the ankles. His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand grasping the wing of the youthful figure to the right. His right arm is bent at the elbow; he holds in his right hand a pair of scissors with which he is about to cut the tip of the youth's right wing. This youthful male figure, nude and striding energetically to the right, is a winged Cupid, cherub, or angel. His legs are spread apart, as though running to the right; he may be fleeing from the old man. The youth's hair is curly. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow, with the fingers of his raised right hand spread apart. His body faces to the right, but we see only the back of his head as he looks back to the sun rising or setting on the distant horizon. Lines of radiance emanate from the sun. A tree, its leafless branches arching over both figures, grows up the left margin. The two figures may be placed on a slight mound or hill.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left of the emblem sits a gowned old man wearing spectacles. He has a long beard and long hair. His eyes are closed or looking sharply down. He may be blind or partly blind. His legs, with prominent knees, are crossed at the ankles. His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand grasping the wing of the youthful figure to the right. His right arm is bent at the elbow; he holds in his right hand a pair of scissors with which he is about to cut the tip of the youth's right wing.

A winged and youthful male figure, nude and striding energetically to the right, is a winged Cupid, cherub, or angel. His legs are spread apart, as though running to the right; he may be fleeing from the old man. The youth's hair is curly. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow, with the fingers of his raised right hand spread apart. A few lines indicate the youth's genitals. His body faces to the right, but we see only the back of his head as he looks back to the sun rising or setting on the distant horizon.
We see about half the sun rising or setting. Radiant beams of light emanate from it.
A tree, its leafless branches arching over both figures, grows up the left margin. The horizon line suggests that the two figures may be on a slight mound or hill.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the partly erased central emblem, an indeterminate figure is visible. Only the head is distinct; what may be arms or wings are extended downward, and the figure may be soaring from right to left.

component.illusobjdesc: In the erased central emblem, an indeterminate figure is visible. Only the head is distinct; what may be arms or wings are extended downward, and the figure may be soaring from right to left.

objnote.p: The central drawing is very similar to, and possibly the preliminary sketch for, the two figures pictured above the text in "London" in *Songs of Experience*, Bentley Plate 46. The drawing in the lower half of this page is a preliminary drawing for the large color print, *Elohim Creating Adam*, Butlin 289 and 290.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem an old man stands or walks facing left, being led by a youth. The old man's legs are bent and he supports himself with crutches. He is very slender, perhaps emaciated. The child holds the old man's right hand with his left, leading him to the left. The child's right arm is also raised at about 45 degrees and he may be pointing with his right hand. Above and to the right of the central emblem is the left profile of a long-haired male with mouth open. At the bottom of the page is a sketch of the Elohim creating Adam, a design more fully developed in Blake's large color prints (Butlin 289 and 290). Elohim, bearded and old with long hair and large wings, hovers over the supine form of Adam. Elohim's arms are exended vertically (relative to his body, but horizontally relative to the bottom of the page), and he reaches with his right hand, grasping (and in a sense sculpting) the head of Adam, whom he is creating. Elohim is gowned and faces to the right, possibly looking down at Adam or at his own left hand reaching for material out of which he forms the first human. Adam lies supine and limp beneath the hovering form of his creator. Adam's partially formed head, which Elohim is fashioning, is bent back. His emaciated left arm is at his side; perhaps we can also see his exposed ribs or organs below his chest. His hands and feet are net yet formed and look like branches on a tree or possibly sinews and veins.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem an old man stands or walks facing left, being led by a youth. The old man's legs are bent and he supports himself with crutches. He is very slender, perhaps emaciated.

A child holds the old man's right hand with his left, leading him to the left. The child's right arm is also raised at 45 degrees and he may be pointing with his right hand. Its facial features are indeterminate.
Above and to the right of the central emblem is the left profile of a long-haired male with mouth open. He might be wearing a cap.

Elohim, bearded and old with long hair and large wings, hovers over the supine form of Adam. His arms are exended vertically (relative to his body, but horizontally relative to the bottom of the page), and he reaches with his right hand, grasping (and in a sense sculpting) the head of Adam, whom he is creating. Elohim is gowned and faces to the right, possibly looking down at Adam or at his own left hand reaching for material out of which he forms the first human.

Adam lies supine and limp beneath the hovering form of his creator, Elohim. Adam's partially formed head, which Elohim is fashioning, is bent back. His mouth may be slightly open. His emaciated left arm is at his side; perhaps we can also see his exposed ribs or organs below his chest. His hands and feet are net yet formed and look like branches on a tree or possibly sinews and veins.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, two or three figures are framed by an archway with two pillars. Seen in right profile, a seated and hooded(?) figure of a male(?) has its head down, looking at the child kneeling before him. The arms of the seated figure appear to be resting on lap. A few light pencil lines above and right of the this figure's head might be another figure, or possibly an alternative position for the frontmost figure. A child, seen in profile and facing left, is kneeling before the seated figure. Its left arm is raised horizontally toward the seated figure. In the upper left corner of the page, A spiral wire or string winds upward around a candlestick. A few very light pencil lines below the central emblem might be a standing figure facing left.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile and facing right, a seated and hooded(?) figure of a male(?) has its head down, looking at the child kneeling before him. The arms of the seated figure appear to be resting on his lap. A few light pencil lines above and right of the this figure's head might be another figure, or possibly an alternative position for the frontmost figure.
A child, seen in profile and facing left, is kneeling before the seated figure(s). Its left arm is raised horizontally toward the seated figure.
The larger figure sits on a chair.
The seated and kneeling figures are framed by an archway with two pillars.
A spiral wire or string sconce winds upward around a candlestick, which is held by a saucer. the wire or strong presumably serves as a handle from which the candlestick may be hung.
A few very light pencil lines below the central emblem might be a standing figure facing left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a nude female(?) figure with streaming long hair is poised on a cliff edge. Her body faces left with her bent right leg poised on the cliff edge, but her upper body and head are twisted so that she is looking back to the right at the figures behind her, whom she may be fleeing. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms out, and her left leg is extended backward and being grabbed at the ankle by one of the figures on the right. The other figure (partly erased?) may be thrusting a sword toward her. Only the heads and one arm of each pursuing figure are visible. There may be rocks or vegetation below the cliff edge in the lower left corner of the emblem.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a nude female(?) figure with streaming long hair is poised on a cliff edge. Her body faces left with her bent right leg poised on the cliff edge, but her upper body and head are twisted so that she is looking back to the right at the figures behind her, whom she may be fleeing. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms out, and her left leg is extended backward, being grabbed at the ankle by one of the figures.

component.characteristic: Two figures pursue the female towards the cliff edge. Only the heads and one arm of each figure are visible, the rest of their bodies cut off by the right border of the emblem. The figure behind, possibly erased in part, may be thrusting a sword toward the female. The figure in front reaches toward the female, clasping her left ankle.

component.illusobjdesc: The figures are located on or near the edge of a cliff.
There may be rocks or vegetation (plants or distant trees?) below, in the lower left corner of the emblem.

objnote.p: The central drawing is very similar to, and possibly the preliminary sketch for, the figure below the text in the "Introduction" to *Songs of Experience*, Bentley Plate 30.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a nude(?) figure, probably female, reclines on her right side on a cloud-like couch or bed that terminates at her feet in serpentine drapery. There may be a cushion or pillow beheath her right elbow. She is seen from behind, with her head turned to the left. She rests on her right arm and draws her right leg under her left, which is fully extended. Her hair might be pulled up into a bun. In the background are what may be clouds and stars.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude(?) figure, probably female, reclines on her right side on a cloud-like couch or bed that terminates at her feet in serpentine drapery. There may be a cushion or pillow beheath her right elbow. She is seen from behind, with her head turned to the left. She rests on her right arm and draws her right leg under her left, which is fully extended. Her hair might be pulled up into a bun.
A nude male figure reclines on a cloud-like couch or bed that terminates at his feet in serpentine drapery. There may be a cushion or pillow beneath his right elbow.
In the background above the figure are what may be clouds and (two?) stars.

objnote.p: The central drawing may be a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 12 in both versions. See also Object 63.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem wavy horizontal lines indicate a sea, from which extends a human (right?) arm, raised vertically, palm probably out and fingers spread apart. In the upper left a figure of indeterminate gender is huddled in front of what may be a willow or banyan tree. In the upper right is a barren tree with exposed roots. A figure of indeterminate gender may be seated on the roots and is holding onto the trunk, possibly climbing the tree.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem wavy lines indicate a sea.
In the central emblem wavy horizontal lines indicate a sea, from which extends a human (right?) arm, raised vertically, palm probably out toward the viewer and fingers spread apart.
In the upper left is what may be a willow or banyan tree with hanging branches.
A figure of indeterminate gender is huddled, facing forward with legs crossed, in front of what may be a willow or banyan tree. The knees are prominent.
In the upper right is a barren tree with exposed roots.
A figure, facing left, of indeterminate gender sit on the roots and is holding onto the trunk with its left arm raised at 135 degrees. The figure may be climbling the tree.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 14 in both versions.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated male figures. The central figure, facing forward, is old and bearded; the others appear to be younger. The central figure, and the two figures next to him, appear to be sitting on a low stone step or possibly on the floor. There may be small windows with bars above them. The larger, older central figure has his legs drawn up; his knees are very prominent. He may be wearing breeches. His face suggests despair. Immediately to the left, very close to the old man, is a young man with legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His knees are also prominent. His body faces forward, but his head is turned up and to the right; he may be looking at the face of the old man. On the right is another young male close to the old man. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, with prominent knees. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the left, with his face pressed against the body or left leg of the old man. Another youthful male sits in the right foreground. His legs are extended but slightly bent at the knees. His left arm is at his side, with his left hand on the floor. He faces left, with his head bent back and looking up. In the left foreground is the final youthful figure, seated and with legs extended. He faces to the right, with his head down. His right arm is at is side, with his right hand on the floor. Given the configuration of the males, the setting, and the compositional relationship to several drawings by Blake, this design would seem to be inspired by Dante's description of Count Ugolino and his sons in prison. Below this central emblem is a detailed view of one of the sons, squatting or sitting with knees facing forward and body twisted to the left so that the head is seen in profile.

component.illusobjdesc: Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated figures. The central, older figure and the two younger figures next to him appear to be sitting on a low stone step or on the floor. There might be small windows with bars above them.

Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated male figures. Given the configuration of these figures, the setting, and the compositional relationship to several drawings by Blake, this design would seem to be inspired by Dante's description of Count Ugolino and his sons in prison. All appear to be dying in pain and despair.

The central seated figure, male, in this group of five faces forward. He is old and bearded. He has his legs drawn up; his knees are very prominent. He may be wearing breeches. His face suggests despair or worse. He may be Ugolino.

A youthful male sits left of the old man in the center of the design. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His knees are prominent. His body faces forward, but his head is turned up and to the right; he may be looking at the face of the old man.

A youthful male sits right of the old man in the center of the design. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, with prominent knees. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the left, with his face pressed against the body or left leg of the old man.

A youthful male sits in the lower right corner of the cell. His legs are extended but slightly bent at the knees. His left arm is at his side, with his left hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor). He faces left, with his head bent back and looking up.
A youthful male sits in the lower left corner of the cell. He faces to the right, with his head down. His right arm is at is side, with his right hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor).
Below the emblem is a detailed view of one of the sons of Ugolino, squatting or sitting with knees facing forward and body twisted to the left so that the head is seen in profile.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, A female, facing forward and to the left, is being embraced mid-leap by a male behind her. Her head is bent back, her arms are raised at 135 degrees and her left leg is extended behind her. She may wear a short gown. She could either be dancing or trying to flee the male's embrace. The male stands directly behind her with legs spread, facing forward and twisted to the left, embracing or seizing the female, his left arm wrapped around her midsection.

component.illusobjdesc: A female, facing forward and to the left, is being embraced mid-leap by a male behind her. She may wear a short gown. Her head is bent back, her arms are raised at 135 degrees and her left leg is extended behind her. She could either be dancing or trying to flee the male's embrace.
Directly behind the female a male, perhaps another dancer, stands with legs spread facing forward and twisted to the left, embracing or seizing the female, his left arm wrapped around her midsection.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 15 in both versions. The text inscribed in pencil below this drawing, "What we hope we see", serves as a caption. The drawing of an arm raised vertically may be relate to the composition of *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 12 in both versions (see also Object 60 here).

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem is a low bed (or possibly a bier) beside which several figures crouch. There appears be a gowned body lying supine and perhaps dead or dying on the bed. Its face is hidden by a male figure in the foreground. At the supine figure's feet, hovering in the air at a 45 degree angle from lower left to upper right, is a gowned and bearded old man. He is probably a spirit (possibly even God) of some sort or the soul of the dead man. His hair is long and he faces to the right. His left arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised horizontally across his body. His right arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised vertically. The index finger (and perhaps a second finger) of his right hand points upward. In the foreground on the right is a male with curly hair. He squats or kneels on his right leg, bent under his body; his left leg is extended to the left and bent slightly at the knee. His left arm is at his side, with the fingers of his left hand spread apart. He is looking to the left at the figure hoveringing above the bed. Behind the bed is the head and upper body of a gowned woman wearing a scarf or hood over her head. Her right arm is extended nearly horizontally along the bed and the fingers of her right hand are spread. She also looks up and to the left at the hovering figure. Behind her and to the left are what may be the heads of two other small figures, perhaps children. This group of figures may constitute a family. To the left and slightly above this central emblem is a detail of a head, shoulder, and vertically raised right arm with outstretched fingers.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem is a low bed (or possibly a bier) beside which several figures crouch.
The group of figures crouched around the bed in the central emblem may be a family.
A gowned body, perhaps dead or dying, may be lying supine on the bed. His face is hidden by the male figure in the foreground.

At the supine figure's feet, hovering in the air at a 45 degree angle from lower left to upper right, is a gowned and bearded old man. He may be a spirit of some sort (possibly even God) or the soul of the dead man. His hair is long and he faces to the right. His left arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised horizontally across his body. His right arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised vertically. The index finger (and perhaps a second finger) of his right hand points upward.

In the foreground on the right is a male with curly hair. He squats or kneels on his right leg, bent under his body; his left leg is extended to the left and bent slightly at the knee. His left arm is at his side, with the fingers of his left hand spread apart. He is looking to the left at the figure hovering above the bed.

Behind the bed is the head and upper body of a gowned woman wearing a scarf or hood over her head. Her right arm is extended nearly horizontally along the bed and the fingers of he right hand are spread. She also looks up and to the left at the hovering figure.
Behind the female figure and to the left are what may be the heads of two other small figures, perhaps children.
To the left and slightly above the central emblem is a detail of a head, shoulder, and vertically raised right arm with outstretched fingers.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 3 in both versions. The text written in pencil below this drawing, "I found him beneath a tree in the Garden", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a tree grows up the right margin, with branches arching toward the left in the top third of the image. Its long, dangling branches and/or leaves suggest it may be a willow. A few small plants with large leaves cover the ground at the base of the trunk. To the left, below the tree's larges branch, is a gowned woman striding to the right with legs spread apart. Her hair is long. Her right arm is bent at the elbow and she may be holding the blossom of a flower or plant. This arm also presses a purse or satchel which is hanging from a strap or belt over her right shoulder. The woman leans over and faces down. Due to reworking, two reaching left arms are visible: one extends nearly vertically downward to a cluster of vegetation near the base of the tree. The second reaching arm, slightly bent at the elbow, appears to be pulling a child or infant out of the earth. We see this child only from the chest up, emerging from a cluster of vegetation; his or her hair stands on end and his or her arms are raised at 135 degrees. The position of the child suggests that it is the anthropomorphic form of a vegetable, probably a mandrake, traditionally thought to be shaped like a human body. Below this emblem is a detail drawing of the woman's hand grasping the mandrake/child's leaves/hair.

component.illusobjdesc: A large tree grows up the right margin, with branches arching toward the left in the top third of the central emblem. Its long, dangling branches and/or leaves suggest it may be a willow.
A few small plants with large, spiky leaves cover the ground at the base of the tree trunk. Another cluster of vegetation, with differently shaped leaves, is visible in the foreground.

A gowned woman strides to the right with legs spread apart. Her hair is long. Her right arm is bent at the elbow and she may be holding the blossom of a flower or plant. This arm also presses a purse or satchel which is hanging from a strap or belt over her right shoulder. The woman leans over and faces down. Due perhaps to reworking, two reaching left arms are visible: one extends nearly vertically downward to a cluster of vegetation near the base of the tree. The second reaching arm, slightly bent at the elbow, appears to be pulling a child or infant out of the earth.

The woman reaches down with her left hand and appears to be pulling a child or infant out of the earth. We see this child only from the chest up, emerging from a cluster of vegetation; his or her stands on end and his or her arms are raised at 135 degrees. The position of the child suggests that it is the anthropomorphic form of a vegetable, perhaps a mandrake, traditionally thought to be shaped like a human body.

Below the central emblem is a detail drawing of the woman's hand grasping the mandrake/child's leaves/hair. In this detail, however, the woman's hand is closer to the child's head and may be grasping it directly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page are two figures of uncertain gender. One may be seated and holding the other limp figure across its lap. The seated figure leans forward, head bent down, over the supine body of the figure on its lap so that the seated figure's arms are dangling downward. The limp figure may be dead; it faces upward and its legs are dangling.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page are two indeterminate figures. One may be seated and holding the other limp figure across its lap. The seated figure leans forward, head bent down, over the supine body of the figure on its lap so that the seated figure's arms are dangling downward.
Lying across the lap of the seated figure is a limp, supine, perhaps dead figure facing up. Its legs are dangling from the lap of the seated figure.

objnote.p: The central drawing is very similar to, and possibly the preliminary sketch for, the two figures pictured above the text in "The Angel" in *Songs of Experience*, Bentley Plate 41.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a long-haired female reclines on the ground, resting her head on her left hand and facing down as she reaches up and back with her right, pushing (perhaps also holding) the face of a male child standing behind her. His left arm lies along her right as his right arm reaches across his body to touch her right arm. He is nude, with the suggestion of genitals, and has short, curly hair. The female may be gowned, although a line at her waist suggest a skirt. There is the suggestion of vegetation, perhaps leafy trees or shrubbery, behind the two figures.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned, long-haired female reclines on the ground, resting her head on her left hand and facing down as she reaches up and back with her right, pushing (perhaps also holding) the face of a male child standing behind her. She may be gowned, although a line at her waist suggests a skirt. Her posture suggests melancholy.

A nude child stands behind the female, who pushes (or holds) his face. He faces forward and his left arm lies along her right as his right hand reaches across his body to touch her right arm. He is nude, with the suggestion of genitals, and has short, curly hair, and is bending backward slightly.
There is the suggestion of vegetation, perhaps leafy trees or shrubbery, behind the two figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the page, a male figure kneels with legs spread, half astride a reclining figure, whom the kneeling figure reaches toward and perhaps touches with his extended left hand. Both figures are very lightly sketched, particularly the one kneeling. The kneeling figure, who is facing forward and slightly to the right, raises his right arm at 135 degrees, and his head appears to be bent back. The reclining figure is perhaps nude, facing forward. His legs appear to be bent, as is his right arm, which is crossed over his left bicep. His left arm is also bent and he rests his head, facing down, on his left hand. Both figures are on a cloud. At the top of the page is the face and part of the head of a man in left profile, perhaps William Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the page, a male figure kneels with legs spread, half astride a reclining figure, whom the kneeling figure reaches toward and perhaps touches with his extended left hand. The kneeling figure, who is facing forward and slightly to the right, raises his right arm at 135 degrees, and his head appears to be bent back.

The kneeling figure is half astride another nude(?) male who reclines on his side, facing forward. His legs appear to be bent, as is his right arm, which is crossed over his left bicep. His left arm is also bent and he rests his head--facing down--on his left hand. Both figures are on a cloud.
The two central figures kneel and recline on a cloud.
At the top of the page is drawn the face and part of the head of a man in left profile, perhaps William Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, One or two tall robed(?) figures of indeterminate gender walk or stand facing left. A small building with an arched doorway appears on the right. In the upper left of the page is a self-portrait of William Blake, in left profile, with wisps of long curly hair.

component.illusobjdesc: One or two tall gowned(?) figures of indeterminate gender walk or stand facing left.
To the right of the figure(s) in the central emblem is a building with an arched doorway and a pitched roof.
In the upper left of the page is a self-portrait of William Blake, in left profile, with wisps of long curly hair.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 1 in both versions. The lines written in pencil beneath this drawing, beginning, "What is Man...", may serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem are two large leaves, perhaps oak leaves. The veins on the upper leaf are particularly prominent. The upper leaf bears a large caterpillar which may be eating the edge of the upper leaf. The lower leaf cradles an infant, or at least the head of an infant, whose body suggests both swaddling bands and a chrysalis.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem are two large leaves, perhaps oak leaves. The veins on the upper leaf are particularly prominent.

component.characteristic: A large caterpillar rests on the edge of, and may be eating, the upper leaf.

component.illusobjdesc: The lower leaf cradles an infant, or at least the head of an infant facing up, whose body suggests both swaddling bands and a chrysalis. The infant's eyes may be closed; he may be sleeping.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 8 in both versions. Lines written in pencil below this drawing, "At length for hatching ripe he breaks / the shell Dryden", serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, an infant or young child, nude and probably male, emerges like a hatchling from a broken egg. Given his wings, he may be a putto, cherub, or angel. His legs are crossed at the ankles; his left arm is bent. He faces forward, with his head up and eyes raised. In the upper left corner is a face with open mouth and staring eyes, perhaps a mask. To the right of this is what may be the detail of an eye.

component.illusobjdesc: A child, putto, cherub, or angel emerges from a broken egg.

In the central emblem, an infant or young child, nude and probably male, emerges like a hatchling from a broken egg. Given his wings, he may be a putto, cherub, or angel. His legs are crossed at the ankles; his left arm is bent. He faces forward, with his head up and eyes raised.
In the upper left is a face with open mouth and staring eyes, perhaps a mask. The expression of the face suggests fear.
To the right of the face is the detail of what might be an eye, looking slightly upward.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page stands a group of figures: two female(?) adults and three or four children. The frontmost female probably faces forward and raises her left arm at 135 degrees, palm down. Behind and to the right is another female(?) whose head and left arm are visible, as well as a portion of her upper body. She raises her left arm at 135 degrees, palm up, mirroring the gesture of the woman in front. To the left of the two adults stands a child of indeterminate gender, facing right and pressed against the left leg and hip of the frontmost adult. The child's (left?) arm is raised vertically, palm up. To the right of the frontmost woman, a child of indeterminate gender stands, seen from behind, with arms spread nearly horizontally. The child might be embracing the woman and children on either side of it. To the right of the child seen from behind stand one or two children of indeterminate gender, facing forward or left. A left arm appears to be at the side of the right-most child. Behind the group of figures in the center of the page is a bench, bed, or couch, very lightly sketched or partly erased. In the upper left corner of the page is a male face facing forward and left in quarter profile.

component.illusobjdesc: A female stands, probably facing forward, raising her left arm at 135 degrees, palm down.

Behind and to the right of the frontmost adult is the head, left arm, and upper body another female(?) figure. but she raises her left arm at 135 degrees, palm up, mirroring the gesture of the woman in front of her.

To the left of the two adults stands a child of indeterminate gender, facing right and pressed against the left leg and hip of the frontmost woman. The child's (left?) arm is raised vertically, palm up.

To the right of the frontmost woman, a child of indeterminate gender stands, seen from behind, with arms spread nearly horizontally. The child may be embracing the woman and children on either side of it.
To the right of the child seen from behind stand one or two children of indeterminate gender, facing forward or left. A left arm appears to be at the side of the right-most child.
Behind the group of figures in the center of the page is a couch, bed, or bench, very lightly sketched or partly erased.

component.characteristic: In the upper left corner of the page is a male face facing forward and left in quarter profile.

objnote.p: A piece, 7.4 x 11.3 cm., of the leaf bearing Objects 73-74 was cut out and removed. This was probably done by Dante Gabriel Rossetti after his acquisition of the work on 30 April 1847. The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 17 in both versions. The words in pencil written below the drawing, "Deaths door", serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The image of the central emblem is of an entrance to a building, wall, or tomb. The posts and lintel of this structure are made of blocks of stone. Into this doorway steps an old man leaning on a single crutch under his left arm. He apparently holds the crutch with his left hand. He has a beard and what appears to be long hair streaming to the left, the direction in which he is facing, as though shaped by a wind blowing from right to left and into the tomb or chamber. His left foot is on tiptoe; his right foot and leg are not pictured beneath his long gown. Given the caption, "Deaths door", the man is entering his tomb and thus dying.

component.illusobjdesc: The image of the central emblem is of an entrance to a building, wall, or tomb. The posts and lintel of this structure are made of blocks of stone.

Into the doorway steps an old man leaning on a single crutch under his left arm. He apparently holds the crutch with his left hand. He has a beard and what appears to be long hair streaming to the left, the direction in which he is facing, as though shaped by a wind blowing from right to left and into the tomb or chamber. His left foot is on tiptoe; his right foot and leg are not pictured beneath his long gown. Given the caption, "Deaths door", the man is entering his tomb and thus dying.

objnote.p: A piece, 7.4 x 11.3 cm., of the leaf bearing objects 73-74 was cut out and removed. This was probably done by Dante Gabriel Rossetti after his acquisition of the work on 30 April 1847. The central drawing is very similar to the figure running over the waves in the title page of *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley plate 2.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, part of which is missing along with most of the top half of the page, a female figure runs or leaps toward the viewer, her arms extended and raised at 135 degrees. She may be Oothoon running across waves, as depicted on the title page of Visions of the Daughters of Albion. To her right may be the crossed legs of another figure, the top half of whom is missing due to the cut away part of the leaf. Clouds fill the sky right and left of the woman.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, part of which is missing along with most of the top half of the page, a female figure runs or leaps toward the viewer, her arms extended and raised at 135 degrees, her right leg extended backward. She may be Oothoon running across waves, as depicted on the title page of Visions of the Daughters of Albion.
Wavy lines at the feet of the figure suggest a sea or body of water across which she is running.
Clouds fill the sky right and left of the woman.
To the right of the figure may be the crossed legs of another figure, the top half of whom is missing due to the cut away part of the leaf.

objnote.p: The three drawings of an eagle may be related to Blake's illustrations to "The Eagle," the second ballad in *Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley*, 1802. The eagle second from the top on the left is similar to the eagle in the headpiece to the ballad, but this Notebook drawing is not a direct preliminary for the engraving. The central design may be related to (but is not a direct preliminary for) the standing woman in "Holy Thursday" in *Songs of Experience*, Bentley Plate 33. The text written in pencil below the central emblem design, "Yet can I not perswade / me. though art dead / Milton", serves as a caption. See also Object 76.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned female stands facing left, with long hair and her head down. At her breast she is holding what appears to be a swaddled infant, the head of which is cradled in her left arm. The caption suggests that the infant is dead. Vertical lines behind the woman and child suggest a hanging curtain. On the upper left side of the page are two similar designs, one above the other, of a large descending eagle with wings spread, head facing right and mouth open. Clinging to the neck of both eagles on the upper left side of the page are two gowned figures, each perhaps clutching an infant (whose head is indicated by a smaller circle) in their right arms. Each figure is gowned and upside down, its body bent backward so that the legs curve to the right. The arms of each are raised relative to the body, with elbows bent in order to wrap around the neck of the eagle. The lower figure has a piece of drapery extending from it. The right foot of this figure is also clearly visible. Centered at the top of the page is another eagle, this one rising with wings and head raised. Its head is facing right with mouth open. Clinging to the breast of this eagle are what appear to be three figures indicated by their circular heads. The central figure is uppermost and largest, and appears to be raising its left arm.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned female stands facing left, with long hair and her head down. At her breast she is holding what appears to be a swaddled infant, the head of which is cradled in her left arm. The woman may be wearing shoes.

The woman holds what appears to be an infant, the head of which is cradled in her left arm. The caption suggests that the infant is dead. The infant may be swaddled in a blanket, part of which hangs in front of the woman.
Vertical lines behind the woman and child suggest a hanging curtain.

On the upper left side of the page are two similar designs, one above the other, of a large descending eagle with wings spread, head facing right and mouth open. Clinging to the neck of both eagles is a gowned figure, prehaps clutching an infant in its arm.

Clinging to the neck of both eagles on the upper left side of the page are two gowned figures, each perhaps clutching an infant (whose head is indicated by a smaller circle than the figure's head) in their right arms. Each figure is gowned and upside down, its body bent backward so that the legs curve to the right. The arms of each are raised relative to the body, with elbows bent in order to wrap around the neck of the eagle. The lower figure has a piece of drapery extending from it. The right foot of this figure is also clearly visible.
Centered at the top of the page is another eagle, this one rising with wings and head raised. Its head is facing right with mouth open. Perhaps three figures cling to its breast.

Clinging to the breast of the eagle centered at the top of the page are what appear to be three figures indicated by their circular heads. The central figure is uppermost and largest, and appears to be raising its left arm.

objnote.p: The drawing of a rigid, standing figure with a supine infant or child to the right, upper left quadrant on this page, is very similar to, and possibly the preliminary sketch for, the figures above the text "Holy Thursday" in *Songs of Experience*, Bentley Plate 33. See also Object 75. The squatting, contracted figure, upper right quadrant on this page, is similar to the equally contracted figure in *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 7.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page contains fifteen figures. At the top center of the page is the face of a male in left profile, perhaps bearded. Immediately below and to the right of the upper-most head is the portrait of a curly-haired male, facing forward and smiling. To the right of the curly-haired male face is a gowned female(?) figure, facing forward with legs crossed. Her arms are down in front of her with hands clasped together. Her head is lowered with long hair falling over her face. Below and slightly to the left of the standing female figure in the upper right is a gowned figure of indeterminate gender, sitting cross-legged. The figure faces forward and its knees are drawn up to its upper chest in a very contracted posture. Its legs are crossed at the ankles and its feet are visible below the hem of the gown. The figure's hands rest upon its knees, and its head is bent forward and rests upon its hands. The right-most design on the page is a male face, seen in left profile. Only the facial features are discernible, not the hair, ears, and rest of the head. In the lower right corner of the page, A gowned male(?) figure walks forward, left leg first. His arms are bent upward to hold the hands of the infant who sits on (or hovers in front of) his head. Its arms are raised horizontally to hold the hands of the walking figure, and its legs dangle on either side of the walking figure's head. Both figures are facing forward. Just below the center of the page is a gowned and seated woman, facing right. She sits huddled with legs drawn up and her head bent down so that it appears to be resting on her knees. Her long hair hangs down and her right arm appears to be wrapped around her body. Her right foot is visible. Her posture suggests despair or grief. Nearly centered at the bottom of the page is a bearded(?) male, facing forward, with a pained or despairing expression. He is extremely contracted, and either his knees or shoulders are visible beside his face, and his arms may be wrapped around his head. The figure is tightly surrounded by drapery, an end of which hangs down at the left side of the design, giving a "P" shape to the drapery and contracted figure. A few lines to the right suggest either stones or clouds. In the lower left corner of the page is another contracted male figure, facing forward, only the head and crossed arms of whom are depicted, all of which forms an "O" shape. His mouth is open, with teeth visible, in an expression of pain or despair. Directly above the O-shaped figure in the lower left corner a figure of indeterminate gender kneels in a huddled position, head to the left and legs drawn up. Its head is bent downward and may be resting on its hands in a posture that suggests despair. Above this figure a female hovers in the sky or on a cloud with arms extended and raised at 135 degrees with palms up.
