She faces forward with her body horizontal, so that we see only her chest, face, arms, and hands. Some snake-like drapery trails behind her, forming a curved shape in the air. From the underside of the cloud descends a lightning bolt terminating above a circle, perhaps a moon. To the left and slightly below the two male faces at the top of the page, a gowned woman stands facing forward, legs together and arms at her sides, with her palms raised so that they are facing down. She is looking down and to the right at a child who is lying face up on the ground, perhaps dead. In the upper left corner of the page a figure of indeterminate gender sits facing forward in a huddled position, its legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles and its head bent down between its prominent knees. The position of its angled shins and feet creates a "Y" shape.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the page is the face of a male in left profile, perhaps bearded.
Immediately below and to the right of the upper-most head is the portrait of a curly-haired male, facing forward and smiling.

To the right of the curly-haired male face is a gowned female(?) figure, facing forward with legs crossed. Her arms are down in front of her with hands clasped together. Her head is lowered with her long hair falling over her face.

Below and slightly to the left of the standing male figure in the upper right is a gowned figure of indeterminate gender, sitting cross-legged. The figure faces forward and its knees are drawn up to its upper chest in a very contracted posture. Its legs are crossed at the ankles and its feet are visible below the hem of the gown. The figure's hands rest upon its knees, and in turn its head is bent forward and rests upon its hands.
The right-most design on the page is a male face, seen in left profile. Only the facial features are discernible, not the hair, ears, and rest of the head.

In the lower right corner of the page, sitting on the head (or held and hovering in front of it) of a gowned walking figure is an infant of indeterminate gender. Its arms are raised horizontally to hold the hands of the walking figure, and its legs dangle on either side of the walking figure's face. Both figures are facing forward. This image was modified for the frontispiece of Songs of Experience.

A gowned male(?) figure walks forward, left leg first. His arms are bent upward to hold the hands of the infant who sits on (or hovers in front of) his head. This image was modified for the frontispiece of Songs of Experience.

Just below the center of the page is a gowned and seated woman, facing right. She sits huddled with legs drawn up and her head bent down so that it appears to be resting on her knees. Her long hair hangs down and her right arm appears to be wrapped around her body. Her right foot is visible. Her posture suggests despair or grief.

Nearly centered at the bottom of the page is a bearded(?) male, facing forward, with a pained or despairing expression. He is extremely contracted, and either his knees or shoulders are visible beside his face, and his arms may be wrapped around his head. The figure is tightly surrounded by drapery, an end of which hangs down at the left side of the design, giving a "P" shape to the drapery and contracted figure.
Curving lines right of the contracted figure, bottom center, suggest clouds or stones.

In the lower left corner of the page is another contracted male figure, facing forward, only the head and crossed arms of whom are depicted, all of which forms an "O" shape. His mouth is open, with teeth visible, in an expression of pain or despair.

Directly above the O-shaped figure in the lower left corner a figure of indeterminate gender kneels in a huddled position, head to the left and legs drawn up. Its head is bent downward and may be resting on its hands in a posture that suggests despair. The figure may be wearing a belt.

A female hovers in the sky or on a cloud with arms extended and raised at 135 degrees with palms up. She faces forward with her body horizontal, so that we see only her chest, face, arms, and hands. Some snake-like drapery trails behind her, forming a curved shape in the air.
The female on the middle left side of the page hovers above a cloud, from which descends a lightning bolt terminating above a circle, perhaps a moon.

To the left and slightly below the two male faces at the top of the page, a gowned woman stands facing forward, legs together and arms at her sides, with her palms raised so that they are facing down. She is looking down and to the right at a child who is lying face up on the ground, perhaps dead. The woman may be the child's mother.
To the right of the standing woman is a child of indeterminate, rigid and lying supine with its head to the right, facing up. It is probably dead.
contracted

In the upper left corner of the page a figure of indeterminate gender sits facing forward in a huddled position, its legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles and its head bent down between its prominent knees. The position of its angled shins and feet creates a "Y" shape.

objnote.p: The text written in pencil below the design upper right, "A vision of fear", serves as its caption. The text written in pencil right of the central design, "A vision of hope", serves as its caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page features a central emblem surrounded by seven separate designs. In the central emblem, two kneeling figures embrace with a child between them. The figure on the left, perhaps female, has her right leg extended backward, her head bent back, and her right arm raised at 135 degrees relative to her body as she embraces the larger figure facing it. The figure on the right, perhaps male, faces left, kneeling on his left knee. The child between them faces left, has its left leg bent, and its left arm raised at 135 degrees as it seems to embrace the figure on the left. In the upper left corner of the page is a head encircled by what appears to be some kind of drapery or scarf, the end of which hangs from the left side of the encircled head. Centered at the top of the page is a seated figure (although no chair is visible), facing right, with head down and right arm on its knee. In the upper right a muscular, nude male falls head-first. His knees are sharply bent and his legs are spread. He seems to grasp his head with both hands in a gesture indicating despair. Between the spread legs of the falling figure is a human (and apparently male) head, facing forward, with mouth open and a pained and despairing expression. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery suggestive of a spiral. The end of the drapery coils above the figure's head, forming one loop. Alternatively, this may be the body of a snake rather than drapery. The caption for the design indicates that it is a vision of fear. In the lower right of the page can be seen the long hair of what might be a beard, though the head from which it descends is indistinct. Centered at the bottom of the page is a figure, seated on a stone or a mound, facing forward. Its right arm reaches across its body, with its elbow on the left knee and arm wrapped around the head, which is lowered. The posture suggests despair or melancholy. In the lower left of the page an old robed man stands facing forward. He has long hair and a beard and his hands are clasped together at his chest. Halfway down the left side of the page is a nude male figure with legs spread, facing forward but with body bent backward so that it is nearly horizontal, with his head bent back. His right arm is extended horizontally and his left arm seems to be bent upward, almost vertically, above him. Either his fingers are spread or his arm terminates in what might be a star.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, two kneeling figures embrace with a child between them. The figure on the left, perhaps female, has her right leg extended backward, her head bent back, and her right arm raised at 135 degrees as it embraces the larger figure facing it. The figure on the right, perhaps male, faces left, kneeling on his left knee. The child between them faces left, has its left leg bent, and its left arm raised at 135 degrees to embrace the figure on the left.
In the upper left is a head encircled by what appears to be some kind of drapery or scarf, the end of which hangs from the left side of the encircled head.
Centered at the top of the page is a seated figure (although no chair is visible), facing right, with head down and right arm on its knee.
In the upper right a muscular, nude male falls head-first. His knees are sharply bent and his legs are spread. He seems to grasp his head with both hands in a gesture indicating despair.

Between the spread legs of the falling figure is a human (and apparently male) head, facing forward, with mouth open and a pained and despairing expression. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery suggestive of a spiral. The end of the drapery coils above the figure's head, forming one loop. Alternatively, this may be the body of a snake rather than drapery. The caption of the design indicates that it is a vision of fear.
In the lower right can be seen the long hair of what might be a beard, though the head from which it descends is indistinct.

Centered at the bottom of the page is a figure, seated on a stone or a mound, facing forward. Its right arm reaches across its body, with its elbow on the left knee and arm wrapped around the head, which is lowered. The posture suggests despair or melancholy.
In the lower left corner of the page an old robed man stands facing forward. He has long hair and a beard and his hands are clasped together at his chest.

Halfway down the left side of the page is a nude male figure with legs spread, facing forward but with body bent backward so that it is nearly horizontal, with his head bent back. His right arm is extended horizontally and his left arm seems to be bent upward, almost vertically, above him. Either his fingers are spread or his arm terminates in what might be a star.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page are three standing, gowned women, surrounded by five children, three to the left (only the head of the third is visible) and two to the right. Several of the children appear to be gowned, and their gender is difficult to determine. The women may be looking down at the children, whose heads are raised toward the adults. One child on the left may be reaching up to the woman on the left. The woman on the right has a purse or satchel with a belt or strap over her shoulder.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page are three standing, gowned women, facing forward, surrounded by five children, three to the left (only the head of the third is visible) and two to the right. Several of the children appear to be gowned, and their gender is difficult to determine. The women may be looking down at the children, whose heads are raised toward the adults. One child on the left may be reaching up to the woman on the left. The woman on the right has a purse or satchel over her shoulder.
The woman on the right has a purse or satchel on a strap or belt over her shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper left corner of the central emblem, a nude male infant or child flies or hovers above a cage, perhaps a bird cage, apparently suspended by a rope or string from a diagonal line above. The door of the cage on the left is open. The child, who has curly hair, may be the personified form of a bird just escaping from the cage. He faces forward with arms raised at 135 degrees, and his legs are spread with his left leg forward. Below the central emblem a male infant lies facing upward with his legs crossed at the ankles. His right arm is raised vertically (relative to his body) and his left arm, slightly bent, is at his side. His head is twisted toward the viewer. On the left side of the page, the head, long neck, and part of the shoulders of a young male can be seen, as if he is looking out from behind the emblem. He is in left three-quarter profile.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper left corner of the central emblem, a nude male infant or child flies or hovers above a bird cage. He faces forward with arms raised at 135 degrees, and his legs are spread with his left leg forward. He has curly hair and the fingers on his hands may be spread. He may be a personified form of a bird escaping from the cage to the right.

In the central emblem an infant hovers above an empty bird(?) cage hanging on a rope or string from an indeterminate object indicated only by a diagonal line. The door of the cage to the left is open.

Below the central emblem a male infant lies facing upward with his legs crossed at the ankles. His right arm is raised vertically (relative to his body) and his left arm, slightly bent, is at his side. His head is twisted toward the viewer.
On the left side of the page, the head, long neck, and part of the shoulders of a young male can be seen, as if he is looking out from behind the emblem. He is in left three-quarter profile.

objnote.p: The drawing is a preliminary sketch for *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 11.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center design, A female hovers above or on a cloud with arms extended horizontally. In the etched version of the design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion she is Oothoon and the figures below are the Daughters of Albion. We see only her unclothed chest, arms and hands, face, and long hair streaming out on each side of her head. She faces forward with a serious, perhaps worried, expression. Her mouth is open and she may be speaking to the women below. Flames emanate from beneath her chest and curl over her arms. One of what may be the Daughters of Albion huddles in a seated or squatting position, the left-most figure in a group of three women. Her legs are drawn up to her chest. She faces to the right and looks up at the hovering figure above her. Another woman sits in the center of the group of three huddled on the seashore. Both legs are drawn up toward her chest, and they may be crossed at the ankles. Her left arm extends horizontally to the left and her left hand rests on the right shoulder of her companion on the left. She may be embracing her companion. She faces right and looks up to the figure hovering above. We only see her legs, drawn up to her chest, and her head of the rightmost figure in the group. Her head it may be lowered, or she may be looking upward like her companions. The setting of the emblem is the seashore, with the sea on the right and the three seated figures on the shore to the left. Slight indications of waves appear in the sea. A crescent shape above the head of the central woman on the left might be the moon; diagonal lines on the right might be rain descending from the clouds above.

component.illusobjdesc: A female hovers above or on a cloud with arms extended horizontally. In the etched version of the design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion she is Oothoon and the figures below are the Daughters of Albion. We see only her unclothed chest, arms and hands, face, and long hair streaming out on each side of her head. She faces forward with a serious, perhaps worried, expression. Her mouth is open and she may be speaking to the women below. Flames emanate from beneath her chest and curl over her arms.
What appears to be fire emanates from below the hovering figure's chest and curls upward over her arms. The tongues of flame are snake-like.

The hovering figure floats above or upon a cloud that extends across the width of the emblem. A crescent shape above the head of the central woman on the left might be the moon; diagonal lines on the right might be rain descending from the clouds above.

One of what may be the Daughters of Albion huddles in a seated or squatting position, the left-most figure in a group of three women. Her legs are drawn up to her chest. She faces to the right and looks up at the hovering figure above her.

One of what may be the Daughters of Albion sits in the center of the group of three huddled women who sit or squat on the seashore. Both legs are drawn up toward her chest, and they may be crossed at the ankles. Her left arm extends horizontally to the left and her left hand rests on the right shoulder of her companion on the left. She may be embracing her companion. She faces right and looks up to the figure hovering above.

One of what may be the Daughters of Albion huddles with two others to the left. We only see her legs, drawn up to her chest, and her head is indeterminate: it may be lowered, or she may be looking upward like her companions.
The setting of the emblem is the seashore, with the sea on the right and the three seated figures on the small mound of the shore to the left. Slight indications of waves appear in the sea.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central emblem is erased and written over, making it difficult to discern. Two groups of figures stand at either end of what may be a bed or bier. A figure on the left may have an arm raised, and there may be two or three children in the group on the right. There may be a coffin alongside the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left side of the erased central emblem stands a group of perhaps two or three figures. One figure might have an arm raised and bent.
On the right side of the emblem stands at least two adult figures and perhaps two or three children (indicated by circular head-shapes).
The two groups of figures stand at either end of what may be a bed or bier. There may be a coffin alongside the figures.

objnote.p: The drawing is closely related to the sketch lower right on Object 18 and more distantly related to the design on *Jerusalem*, Bentley Plate 32.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page a gowned(?) female figure stands facing forward in contrapposto, with her head turned to the left. Similarities between this design and some in Jerusalem suggest that this might be the character Jerusalem. Her arms are raised at 45 degrees with palms down and she is flanked by three children, perhaps her daughters, who press against her. The daughter to her left stands with her head concealed beneath and behind the woman's right arm. This daughter, perhaps gowned, faces toward Jerusalem, perhaps holding her. Her visible right arm is bent upward. The shortest of the three daughters stands to the right of Jerusalem, with her back to us. She appears to be gowned, and may be holding her mother and/or her sister. The tallest of the three daughters stands facing forward to the right of Jerusalem, whose left arm extends behind her head. The daughter may have long hair and her arms are crossed at the wrist in front of her waist. She may be touching or holding the shoulder of the shortest daughter in front of her. To the right of the four figures are what may be two seated or reclining figures—or simply a pile of stones.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page a gowned(?) female figure stands facing forward in contrapposto, with her head turned to the left. Similarities between this design and some in Jerusalem suggest that this might be the character Jerusalem. Her arms are raised at 45 degrees with palms down and she is flanked by three children, perhaps her daughters, who press against her.

To the left of Jerusalem stands what may be one of her daughters, her head concealed beneath and behind Jerusalem's right arm. The daughter, perhaps gowned, faces toward Jerusalem, perhaps holding her. Her visible right arm is bent upward.
The shortest of the three daughters stands to the right of Jerusalem, with her back to us. She appears to be gowned, and may be holding her mother and/or her sister.

The tallest of the three daughters stands facing forward to the right of Jerusalem, whose left arm extends behind her head. The daughter may have long hair and her arms are crossed at the writstin front of her waist. She may be touching or holding the shoulder of the shortest daughter in front of her.
To the right of the four main figures are what may be two seated or reclining figures—or simply a pile of stones.

objnote.p: The central drawing is very similar to, and possibly the preliminary sketch for, a figure upper right on the title page in *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 2.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a nude male sits with legs crossed atop a cloud from which rain descends. His hair is long; he faces down and to the left. He twists and leans to the left, with arms raised horizontally relative to his body and extended downward and to the left. The fingers of both hands are spread and extended as though he were casting down the slight indications of rain below.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a nude male sits with legs crossed atop a rain cloud. His hair is long; he faces down and to the left. He twists and leans to the left, with arms raised horizontally relative to his body and extended downward and to the left. The fingers of both hands are spread and extended as though he were casting down the slight indications of rain below.
The figure sits atop what might be a darkly colored rain cloud, with angled lines suggesting rain descending from it.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the lower right part of the page is an upside-down portrait of a male head in quarter profile. When the page is inverted so that the head is upright, it is facing right. The hair is curly, or the figure may be wearing a wig.

component.illusobjdesc: In the lower right part of the page is an upside-down portrait of a male head in quarter profile. When the page is inverted so that the head is upright, it is facing right. The hair is curly, or the figure may be wearing a wig.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned woman with long hair sits facing forward on a throne-like chair. Her legs may be crossed. On her lap lies a child who appears to be dead, as it is lying supine, rigid, and facing up. The woman raises her hands with the palms vertically facing each other above the child and below her head, a posture which, combined with her facial expression, suggests grief and despair. Her seated figure casts a shadow to the lower right. The top of the chair's back in a pointed arch. Vertical lines indicate a wall in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a gowned woman with long hair sits facing forward on a throne-like chair. Her legs may be crossed. On her lap lies a child who appears to be dead. The woman raises her hands with the palms vertically facing each other above the child and below her head, a posture which, combined with her facial expression, suggests grief and despair. Her seated figure casts a shadow to the lower right.
On the woman's lap is a child, nude, rigid, and lying supine, facing up. It is probably dead.
The woman is seated on a throne-like chair with a pointed arch forming the top of its back. Vertical lines indicate a background wall.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, two figures walk past or regard a figure lying on the ground. The upright figure on the left wears a cloak. The upright figure on the right wears pants and holds a stick or sword. He may be walking with his leg extended backward. The figure on the ground may be dead or dying. It lies horizontally, perhaps wrapped in some kind of cloth or blanket. Above and behind the group of figures is a night sky with a crescent moon in the upper left corner of the emblem. The jagged lines defining the sky suggest a storm. The lines defining the land suggest mounds or low hills.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, two figures walk past or regard a figure supine on the ground. The upright figure on the left wears a cloak. His(?) left arm may be bent upward in front of him, grasping the cloak.

In the central emblem, two figures walk past or regard a figure supine on the ground. The upright figure on the right wears pants and holds a stick or sword. He may be walking with his leg extended backward.
The figure lying on the ground may be dead or dying. It lies horizontally, perhaps wrapped in some kind of cloth or blanket.
The lines defining the land suggest mounds or low hills.
Above and behind the group of figures is a night sky with a crescent moon in the upper left corner of the emblem. The jagged lines defining the sky suggest a storm.

objnote.p: The text written in pencil below the central drawing, "Whose changeless brow / Neer smiles nor frowns / Donne", serves as a caption. The central drawing is similar, in both design and probably in theme, to *Fate*, a pencil sketch of c. 1793 (Butlin 210).

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a bearded, curly-haired male sits cross-legged, facing forward, his bare right foot visible. His hands (crossed at the wrists) and waist appear to be bound and strapped to the stone behind him, which rises above his head to the top of the emblem. The stone may be a mountain peak or an island with slight indications of water below. The quotation from John Donne's "The Progresse of the Soule" has as its antecedent "Great Destiny," and thus this figure may be a personification of Destiny. Above and behind the stone are what appear to be clouds, with a spiral-shaped suggestion of a whirlwind in the upper right corner of the emblem.

component.illusobjdesc: A bearded, curly-haired male sits cross-legged, facing forward, his bare right foot visible. His hands (crossed at the wrists) and waist appear to be bound and strapped to the stone behind him. The quotation from John Donne's "The Progresse of the Soule" has as its antecedent "Great Destiny," and thus this figure may be a personification of Destiny.
The man sits with his back against a stone, which rises above his head to the top of the emblem. The stone may be a mountain peak or an island with suggestions of water below it.
Above and behind the stone are what appear to be clouds, with a spiral-shaped suggestion of a whirlwind in the upper right corner of the emblem.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The image is drawn sideways on the page, and depicts A group of what appear to be three gowned women stand together. The woman in the center of the group faces the woman on the right, and the woman on the left, facing forward(?), is mostly blocked from our view by the woman in the center. The women appear to be looking at some indeterminate object(s) held between them at waist-level.

component.illusobjdesc: A group of what appear to be three gowned women stand together. The woman in the center of the group faces the woman on the right, and the woman on the left, facing forward(?), is mostly blocked from our view by the woman in the center. The women appear to be looking at some indeterminate object(s) held between them at waist-level.

objnote.p: The central drawing may be an early preliminary version of *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 9 in both versions. See also Object 21.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the lower right corner of the central emblem is a rough sketch of what may be a boy leaping or reaching after a figure above and to the left of him. What may be the upper figure's spread arms and legs are indicated by crossed lines. The boy's right(?) arm is raised vertically, and he may be holding a hat. Vertical lines on the left suggest a wall or tree trunks.

component.illusobjdesc: In the lower right corner of the central emblem is a rough sketch of what may be a boy leaping or reaching after a figure above and to the left of him. The boy's right(?) arm is raised vertically, and he may be holding a hat.
In the upper left corner of the central emblem is a very rough sketch of a flying figure that may be fleeing the boy. What may be the figure's spread arms and legs are indicated by crossed lines.
Vertical lines on the left of the central emblem suggest tree trunks or a wall.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. A woman stands on the right facing forward and turned slightly to the left. Her arms are spread and raised horizontally. Her right hand is drawn in two positions, and in one of them she appears to be touching the head of a large serpent that coils behind her, the coils even extending to the right of the woman. She may be Eve in the Garden of Eden.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude(?) woman stands facing forward and turned slightly to the left. Her arms are spread and raised horizontally. Her right hand is drawn in two positions, and in one of them she appears to be touching the head of the serpent that coils behind her. She may be Eve in the Garden of Eden.

A large serpent coils behind the woman, with its rising head to her left. The features of the serpent's head are unclear, but it may be looking up at the woman, who may be touching its head. The serpent's coils form loops right of the woman.
If the woman is Eve, then the setting may be Eden

illustration.illusobjdesc: The mostly erased central emblem appears to be a group of figures, though any further details are unclear. A mother may be bending over a fallen child. In the upper right of the emblem there may be a small, leafless tree, bending to the left. The indeterminate figures are beneath it.

component.illusobjdesc: The mostly erased central emblem appears to be a group of figures, though any further details are unclear. A mother may be bending over a fallen child.
In the upper right of the emblem there may be a small, leafless tree, bending to the left. The indeterminate figures are beneath it.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Along the right margin of the page, which must be rotated to see the figure upright, a curly-haired male lies with legs stretched to the right. He raises himself on his hands so that his upper body is twisted, facing forward, and vertical (relative to the ground). His head is bent back and he may be looking upward. References to Satan in the text on this page suggest the identity of this figure. Above the figure's outstretched legs, in the upper left corner of the page, is a circular object that may be a cloud, the moon, the sun, or a shield. Forms lower left might be clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Along the right margin of the page, which must be rotated to see the figure upright, a curly-haired male lies with legs stretched to the right. He raises himself on his hands so that his upper body is twisted, facing forward, and vertical (relative to the ground). His head is bent back and he may be looking upward. References to Satan in the text on this page suggest the identity of this figure.
Above the figure's outstretched legs, in the upper left corner of the page, is a circular object that may be a cloud, the moon, the sun, or a shield.
Forms lower left on the page might be clouds.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 7 in both versions. The lines written in pencil below this drawing, "Forthwith upright he rears from off the pool / His mighty stature / Milton", serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young and muscular nude male, with curly hair, stands facing forward. His legs are spread apart and his arms raised at approximately 135 degrees. His left arm is slightly bent. He holds a spear in his left hand; a large shield is buckled to his right arm and hand. Flames fill the background of the design and rise over the figure's left lower leg. The caption written below this drawing imply that the figure is Satan and that the setting is hell.

component.illusobjdesc: Flames fill the background and foreground of the design. The fire, character of the figure, and the caption written below the drawing indicate that this is a vision of hell.

A young and muscular nude male, with curly hair, stands facing forward. His legs are spread apart and his arms raised at approximately 135 degrees. His left arm is slightly bent. He holds a spear in his left hand; a large shield is buckled to his right arm and hand. The caption written below the drawing imply that this figure is Satan.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 7. The drawing upper right is a preliminary sketch for Blake's headpiece to "The Elephant," the first ballad in *Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley*, 1802. See also Object 6.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a figure, probably male, is seated, wearing a gown and facing forward. His knees are drawn up to his upper chest in a very contracted posture. His legs may be crossed at the ankles. His hands rest upon his knees, and in turn his head appears to be bent forward and rests upon his hands. The etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion suggest that this is Theotormon. Within a tongue- or flame-like wave is a nude female, shackled and chained on the ankle of an extended left(?) leg. The other leg, as well as her head, neck, and shoulder, cannot be clearly discerned. She arches to the left, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clasped together just below her neck in a gesture that suggests prayer or supplication. Though her face is unclear, her posture suggests that she is facing down. She is probably Oothoon, pleading to her lover Theotormon. Drawn within an oval in the upper right corner of the page is a design also sketched on object 6 of the Notebook. A tiger crouches facing right with mouth open and tail raised. Shading on the tiger indicates fur, but no stripes. It is looking up at slight indications of a figure in a window above the arch doorway of a building to the right of the tiger. There may be pillars or pilasters on both sides of the doorway. The arch appears to be slightly pointed, indicating a Gothic structure. A leafy tree grows to the right of the building; a tower or spire and three domes rise in the distance on the left. This may be a city with a church.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, is seated, wearing a gown and facing forward. His knees are drawn up to his upper chest in a very contracted posture. His legs may be crossed at the ankles. His hands rest upon his knees, and in turn his head appears to be bent forward and rests upon his hands. The etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion suggest this is Theotormon.

Within a tongue- or flame-like wave is a nude female, shackled and chained on the ankle of an extended left(?) leg. The other leg, as well as her head, neck, and shoulder, cannot be clearly discerned. She arches to the left, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clasped together just below her neck in a gesture that suggests prayer or supplication. Though her face is unclear, her posture suggests that she is facing down. The etched version of this design in Visions of the Daughters of Albion suggest that this is Oothoon.
One of the female's feet is shackled and chained.
The female is pictured within a giant wave of water which, in its shape, resembles a tongue of fire.

In a drawing within an oval upper right, a tiger crouches facing right, with mouth open and tail raised. Shading on the tiger indicates fur, but not stripes. It is looking up at what may be the figure of a man in a window above the arch of a building to the right of the tiger.

To the right of the tiger is a building with an arched doorway and a window above. The arch is slightly pointed, suggesting a Gothic structure. There may be pillars or pilasters on both sides of the doorway. The arch is slightly pointed, indicating a Gothic structure. To the right of the building is a tree; to the left are a tower or spire and three domes. These suggest a city with a church.
A leafy tree rises right of the building.
In the window above the arch are slight indications of a figrue, facing right, who appears to be fleeing the tiger.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 5 in both versions. The text written in pencil below this drawing, "Rest Rest perturbed Spirit / Shakespeare", may serve as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a nude man struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. He squats or crouches, with legs spread apart. His right leg is bent sharply at the knee and the left, slightly bent, is extended toward the lower margin of the design. He faces forward, with his arms raised, elbows bent. His hands are above his head; he may be grasping the top of his head with his left hand. His feet are prominent. The general expression is one of conflict, grief, and pain.

component.illusobjdesc: A man struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. This cavern forms a prison for the man within.

In the central emblem a nude man struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. He is imprisoned. He squats or crouches, with legs spread apart. His right leg is bent sharply at the knee and the left, slightly bent, is extended toward the lower margin of the emblem. He faces forward, with his arms raised, elbows bent. His hands are above his head; he may be grasping the top of his head with his left hand. His feet are prominent. The general expression is one of conflict, grief, and pain.

objnote.p: The two versions of the design are preliminary drawings for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 6 in both versions. The text written in pencil below the wash drawing on the left, "Thou hast set thy heart as the / heart of God— Ezekiel", may serve as a caption. See also Object 100.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a youthful nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on what appears to be a cloud. Part of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. He faces forward. Three round objects just within the left margin of the design, and perhaps one upper right, suggest stars. The dark background may indicate a night sky. To the right of this emblem is a nearly identical image, but drawn more lightly and with different proportions. Here the figure is even more contracted; his chin rests on his right knee and his left elbow descends between his knees. Three round objects upper left and possibly a fourth upper right suggest stars. The posture and expression of both figures indicate despair or melancholy.

component.illusobjdesc: The male in the central emblem sits atop what appears to be a cloud formation, part of which extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet.

In the central emblem a youthful nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on what appears to be a cloud. Part of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. His fingers may be intertwined. He faces forward. His posture and expression indicate despair or melancholy.

The figure sits on a cloud. This or another cloud extends behind him; a cloud covers his feet. Three round objects just within the left margin of the design, and perhaps one upper right, suggest stars. The dark background may indicate a night sky.

To the right of the central emblem is a nearly identical image, but drawn more lightly and with different proportions. Here the male also sits atop what appears to be a cloud formation, part of which extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. Three round object upper left, and perhaps a fourth upper right, suggest stars.

To the right of the central emblem a youthful nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on what appears to be a cloud. Part of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. His fingers appear to be intertwined. This figure is more contracted than the figure in the central emblem. Here his chin rests on his right knee and his left elbow descends between his knees. He faces forward. His posture and expression indicate despair or melancholy.

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary sketch for *For Children: The Gates of Paradise*, 1793, later transformed into *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*, Bentley Plate 4 in both versions. The text written in pencil below the drawing, "O that the Everlasting had not fixd / His canon gainst Self slaughter / Shakespeare", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a nude male sits with legs crossed at the ankles. He faces down. His arms reach down with his hands resting on his knees; his palms are open and facing down with fingers spread. He may be sitting on a bank or shore with the water of a river, stream, or lake below. His posture and expression suggest despair.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem a nude male sits with legs crossed at the ankles. He faces down. His arms reach down with his hands resting on his knees; his palms are open and facing down with fingers spread. His posture and expression indicate despair, as does the caption.
The figure may be sitting on a bank or shore with the water of a river, stream, or lake below.

objnote.p: The drawing is similar to, and possibly a preliminary version of, the frontispiece in *Europe a Prophecy*, Bentley Plate 1, also known as *The Ancient of Days* and *God Creating the Universe*. The text written vertically near the top of the page, right of the design when the leaf is rotated, may serve as a caption: "Who shall bind / the Infinite".

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. A nude male crouches and kneels upon a cloud, his right leg bent at the knee, with both right knee and right foot prominent. His left leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back. He is hunched over and appears to be looking down (though facial features are unclear); his right arm is extended downward. He holds what may be a pair of dividers or compasses in his right hand. The figure in the etched version in Europe a Prophecy has been identified variously as God, Urizen, and the Ancient of Days. If those identifications pertain to this drawing, then the figure is creating, measuring, and delimiting the universe.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male crouches and kneels upon a cloud, his right leg bent at the knee, with both right knee and right foot prominent. His left leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back. He is hunched over and appears to be looking down (though facial features are unclear); his right arm is extended downward. He holds what may be a pair of dividers or compasses in his right hand. The figure in the etched version in Europe a Prophecy has been identified variously as God, Urizen, and the Ancient of Days. If those identifications pertain to this drawing, then the figure is creating, measuring, and delimiting the universe.
The figure holds dividers or compasses.
The figure crouches or kneels on, and is surrounded by, clouds.

objnote.p: The central drawing is similar to (but not the direct preliminary for) the crouching figures in *Europe a Prophecy*, Bentley Plate 4, and in Blake's water color, *Malevolence*, Butlin 341.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a male, probably an assassin or murderer, sits in a contracted position at the base of a tree. He faces forward and his legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles so that only his left foot is visible. In his bent right arm he holds what may be a knife or a dagger, and he has a slight smile on his face. Background details in the lower left corner of the emblem suggest a city, or at least a building. Two windows and a roof of one building, and one or two towers are discernible. The dark sky may include clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A male, probably an assassin or murderer, with short hair sits in a contracted position at the base of a tree. He faces forward and his legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles so that only his left foot is visible. In his bent right arm he holds what may be a knife or a dagger, and he has a slight smile on his face.
The figure holds a knife or dagger in his right hand.
The figure sits against the base of a tree, the trunk of which extends up the right side of the emblem. A branch appears to be arching to the left, over the figure, at the top of the emblem.

Background details in the lower left corner of the emblem suggest a city, or at least a building. Two windows and a roof of one building, and one or two towers are discernible. There may be a wall in front of the building.
The dark sky may include clouds.

objnote.p: The figure in this drawing is similar to the emblem drawings in Object 96.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page, which must be rotated to see the figure upright, a male sits, in a crouching posture, on what appears to be a cloud. Part of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. He faces forward. His posture and expression indicate despair or melancholy. He may be wearing a helmet or hood which extends to his chest.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page, which must be rotated to see the figure upright, a male sits, in a crouching posture, on what appears to be a cloud. Part of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extends behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. He faces forward. His posture and expression indicate despair or melancholy. He may be wearing a helmet or hood that extends to his chest.
The figure perhaps sits on and is surrounded by clouds, which may be obscuring his feet.

objnote.p: There appears to have once been a central emblem design on this page, but it is thoroughly erased and no motifs can be discerned.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the seated, reclining figure upright. He faces forward and leans to his left, though it is unclear what he is resting on. His left leg is drawn up with its lower part behind his right leg. His left arm is bent at the elbow and extended upward, with the left hand clasped over his forehead, and perhaps shielding his eyes as he looks into the distance (toward us). His right arm is not clearly pictured. His facial expression may suggest despair or fear at what he sees. There appears to be a crescent moon to the left of the figure, above his right thigh.

component.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the seated, reclining figure upright. He faces forward and leans to his left, though it is unclear what he is resting on. His left leg is drawn up and its lower part behind his right leg. His left arm is bent at the elbow and extended upward, with the left hand clasped over his forehead, and perhaps shielding his eyes as he looks into the distance (toward us). His right arm is not clearly pictured. His facial expression may suggest despair or fear at what he sees.
There appears to be a crescent moon to the left of the figure, above his right thigh.

objnote.p: The line of text written in pencil below the design, "Begone & trouble me no more", serves as a caption.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a male figure appears to be walking toward the viewer with his right leg forward. His head is turned to the left as he looks toward a figure facing away from him. His right arm is extended horizontally and may be touching, even pushing, the figure on the left. His left arm is bent upward and he points at the figure with his left hand. There may be a serpentine vine wrapped around his left calf. The other figure, perhaps female, walks away from the male figure. She faces left, with her head down and resting on her raised left hand. Her posture suggests grief or melancholy.

component.illusobjdesc: In the central emblem, a male figure appears to be walking toward the viewer with his right leg forward. His head is turned to the left as he looks toward the figure facing away from him. His right arm is extended horizontally and may be touching or evening pushing away the figure on the left. His left arm is bent upward and he points at the figure with his left hand.
A figure, perhaps female, walks away from the male figure. She faces left, with her head down and resting on her raised left hand. Her posture suggests grief or melancholy.
There may be a vine coiled serpent-like vine around the male's left calf.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page, which must be rotated to see the figures upright, a nude curly-haired male, perhaps Adam, stands or walks toward the viewer. His right hand appears to be holding the left hand of the nude female, possibly Eve, who walks beside him. Vertical and diagonal lines to the left and right of the couple suggest the trunks of trees among which the figures are walking. The setting may be Eden. Partially erased heads and legs near the couple indicate that they may have been drawn and erased in different positions.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the page, which must be rotated to see the figures upright, a nude curly-haired male, perhaps Adam, stands or walks toward the viewer. His genitals are clearly pictured. His right hand appears to be holding the left hand of the female, possibly Eve, beside him. Partially erased heads and legs near the couple indicate that they may have been drawn and erased in different positions.

To the left of the male figure and holding his right hand with her left is a nude female, possibly Eve, who is also standing or walking toward the viewer, her right arm at her side. Her breasts are clearly pictured. Partially erased heads and legs near the couple indicate that they may have been drawn and erased in different positions.
Vertical and diagonal lines to the left and right of the couple suggest the trunks of trees among which the figures are walking.
If the figures are Adam and Eve, the setting may be Eden.

objnote.p: The drawing is similar to, and probably has the same subject as, Blake's water colors, *Christ Offers to Redeem Man*, in both series of his illustrations to Milton's *Paradise Lost*, Butlin 529.3 and 536.3. See also the composition extending across Objects 112 and 113 of the Notebook.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design, which must be rotated to be seen upright, depicts what may be the Trinity. A figure, perhaps the Holy Ghost, hovers facing forward and down (so that we see what may be the top of its head) with body horizontal and arms and wings spread. Below the Holy Ghost, a male figure, perhaps God the Father, kneels, crouches, or squats in a contracted posture on a cloud, facing forward. His head is down and his arms are extended forward as he embraces a figure, perhaps Christ, who faces him. Christ is hovering with arms spread and legs together and extended back and to the right. His head also appears to be bent back, though no facial features can be determined. In the lower left corner, below the cloud, a figure hovers with body horizontal and head to the right. This may be Satan, as in Blake's water color versions of Christ Offers to Redeem Man in both series of his illustrations to Milton's Paradise Lost, Butlin 529.3 and 536.3. His arms appear to be spread horizontally, but other features are unclear. Directly above the Holy Ghost is the sun, surrounded by clouds. There are lines within the circumference of the sun, but what they depict cannot be determined. Large clouds constitute the background of the design. If the identifications of the figures given here are accurate, then the setting is heaven and the event pictured is the same as in Blake's two water colors, Christ Offers to Redeem Man, in both series of his illustrations to Milton's Paradise Lost, Butlin 529.3 and 536.3.

component.illusobjdesc: The design may depict the Trinity. A figure, perhaps the Holy Ghost, hovers facing forward and down (so that we see what may be the top of its head) with body horizontal and arms and wings spread.

Below the hovering Holy Ghost, a male figure, perhaps God the Father, kneels, crouches, or squats in a contracted posture, facing forward. His head is down and his arms are extended forward as he embraces the figure, perhaps Christ, who faces him.

The kneeling or squatting figure embraces a figure, perhaps Christ, who is seen from behind, hovering with arms raised horizontally and legs together and extended back and to the right. His head also appears to be bent back, though no facial features can be determined.

In the lower left corner, below the cloud, a figure hovers with body horizontal and head to the right. His arms appear to be raised horizontally, but other features are uncertain. This may be Satan, as in Blake's water colors, Christ Offers to Redeem Man, in both series of his illustrations to Milton's Paradise Lost, Butlin 529.3 and 536.3.
Directly above the Holy Ghost is the sun, surrounded by clouds. There are lines within the circumference of the sun, but what they depict cannot be determined.
Large clouds constitute the background of the design, and God the Father may be crouching or sitting on a cloud. The setting is probably heaven.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. A figure flies or hovers beneath what may be another figure in a cloud formation. The lower figure may be facing away from us and flying toward the upper figure, whose head is discernible with what may be long hair blown to the left. Above and to the right of this head is what may be a raised forearm and hand, perhaps belonging to this figure or to another. There may be two compositions here, with one figure drawn over the other.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure flies or hovers beneath what may be another figure in a cloud formation. The lower figure may be facing away from us and flying toward the upper figure.

Above and to the left of the figure with arms spread appears to be at least one other figure amidst what may be clouds. The figure's head is discernible with what may be long hair blown to the left. Above and to the right of the head is what may be a raised forearm and hand, perhaps belonging to this figure or another.
There may be clouds above the figure with arms spread, and wind may be blowing the upper figure's hair to the left.

objnote.p: Texts on this page are related to three *Songs of Experience*, "The Sick Rose," "London," and "The Human Abstract."

illustration.illusobjdesc: Slightly above and to the left of the center of the page is a faint drawing of a figure of indeterminate gender, sitting cross-legged and facing forward with arms perhaps at its sides.

component.illusobjdesc: Slightly above and to the left of the center of the page is a faint drawing of a figure of indeterminate gender, sitting cross-legged and facing forward with arms perhaps at its sides.

objnote.p: The texts on this page are related to "The Tyger" in *Songs of Experience*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. In the upper left of a largely indeterminate design a male figure appears to be rising, facing forward with arms raised horizontally. His head may be bent back and his left knee appears to be drawn up. Below the rising figure there may be other figures, two heads of which are discernible. There may be another figure upper left (upper right when the page is rotated).

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper left of a largely indeterminate design a male figure appears to be rising, facing forward with arms spread. His head may be bent back and his left knee appears to be drawn up.
Below the rising figure there may be other figures, two heads of which might be discernible.

objnote.p: The composition extending across Objects 112 and 113 may represent Christ offering the redeem man—see Object 3 in the Thomas and Butts set of *Paradise Lost* designs, Butlin 529.3 and 536.3. See also Notebook Object 106.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. On a throne in the clouds, an robed old man, probably God, is seated facing forward with his hands on his knees. He has long hair and a beard. Hovering below and to the right of God is a male figure, perhaps Christ, facing left with head bowed down. His left arm may be bent upward and his robe extends beneath him in serpentine coils.

component.illusobjdesc: On a throne in the clouds, an robed old man, probably God, is seated facing forward with his hands on his knees. He has long hair and a beard.
Hovering below and to the right of God is a male figure, perhaps Christ, facing left with head bowed down. His left arm may be bent upward and his robe extends beneath him in serpentine coils.
God is seated on what may be a throne, resting on and surrounded by clouds.

objnote.p: The composition extending across Objects 112 and 113 may represent Christ offering the redeem man—see Object 3 in the Thomas and Butts set of *Paradise Lost* designs, Butlin 529.3 and 536.3. See also Notebook Object 106.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. In a continuation of the drawing on Object 112, a nude figure, perhaps Satan, appears to be hanging or struggling in a web or net that descends from the clouds on Object 112. Satan's body is facing forward with his head to the left. His torso is twisted upward from the horizontal and his head is both turned to the right and bent backwards. He is looking up (toward God and Christ on the cloud in Object 112) with mouth open. His legs are spread but bent so that they are crossed at the ankles. Only his right arm is visible, raised horizontally relative to his torso and bent at the elbow.

component.illusobjdesc: In a continuation of the drawing on object 112, a nude figure, perhaps Satan, appears to be hanging or struggling in a web or net that descends from the clouds on Object 112. Satan's body is facing forward with his head to the left. His torso is twisted upward from the horizontal and his head is both turned to the right and bent backwards. He is looking up (toward God and Christ on the cloud in Object 112) with mouth open. His legs are spread but bent so that they are crossed at the ankles. Only his right arm is visible, raised horizontally relative to his torso and bent at the elbow.
Satan appears to be entrapped in a web or net that descends from the clouds on Object 112.

objnote.p: The soaring figure is very similar to, and possibly a preliminary sketch for, the figure of Satan in Blake's large color print, *Satan Exulting over Eve*, Butlin 291 and 292.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. At the bottom of the design a curly-haired nude male figure, perhaps Satan, rises with head to the left, but with his torso twisted so that his upper body faces the viewer. He is looking to his left and slightly upward. His arms are raised horizontally and he holds a shield on his right arm and a sword or spear in his left hand. His legs appear to be together, extended behind and to the right of him. Numerous circles on either side of Satan suggest the heads of groups of figures. If the setting is hell, these may be more fallen angels become devils. It is unclear what the three large, overlapping circles above the figure might represent. Dark lines surrounding Satan suggest the darkness of night or hell.

component.illusobjdesc: At the bottom of the design a curly-haired nude male figure, perhaps Satan, rises with head to the left, but with his torso twisted so that his upper body faces the viewer. He is looking to his left and slightly upward. His arms are spread and raised horizontally, and he holds a shield on his right arm and a sword in his left hand. His legs appear to be together, extended behind and to the right of him.

Numerous circles on either side of Satan suggest the heads of groups of figures. If the setting is hell, these may be more fallen angels become devils. It is unclear what the three large, overlapping circles above the figure might represent.
Satan holds a shield on his right arm and a sword or spear in his left hand.
Dark lines surrounding Satan suggest the darkness of night or hell. If the latter, the dark horizontal lines may suggest smoke.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page must be rotated to see the design upright. Circles suggest the heads of a row of figures. An additional figure may be flying in the air above and to the right of the row of heads, though the design is quite unclear.

component.illusobjdesc: Circles suggest the heads of a row of figures. An additional figure may be flying in the air above and to the right of the row of heads, though the design is quite unclear.
